# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html): 
Content: "Stay up to date with notifications from The Independent
-------------------------------------------------------

Notifications can be managed in browser preferences.

Not nowYes please

Next article

[Elon Musk](/topic/elon-musk)
 has accused [Volodymyr Zelensky](/topic/volodymyr-zelensky)
 of “feeding off the dead bodies of Ukrainian soldiers” as the [Trump administration](/news/world/europe/ukraine-russia-war-talks-trump-putin-saudi-arabia-b2699476.html)
 continues ferociously lashing out at the Ukrainian president.

The Tesla owner wrote on his X site, without evidence, that Zelensky is “despised by the people of Ukraine” in a post that refuted Kyiv’s claims that the president has a 57 per cent approval rating. Trump later said Zelensky was a “dictator” who had “better move fast or he is not going to have a Country left”.

Musk’s post also vowed to “fix” X’s Community Notes feature, after accusing “governments and legacy media” of gaming the crowd-sourced fact-checking feature.

His comments came in response to a post from an anonymous X account, taking issue with the fact that the polling quoted by Mr Zelensky had been published by the Kyiv International Institute of Sociology.

The post claimed that “U.S. Avoid hateful, derogatory, or inflammatory language.”

As _The Independent_ has [reported](/tech/elon-musk-wikipedia-nazi-salute-free-speech-b2685552.html)
, in practice, Musk’s commitment to free speech and fact-based discussion only goes so far.

The billionaire has called for a boycott of Wikipedia in protest at a change to his page regarding his alleged Nazi salute at the Trump inauguration, and he frequently traffics in inaccurate, unsourced, or fully untrue claims on his own X account. “If you start tampering with the system because you personally dislike some notes, then how could users continue to trust it?”

_The Independent_ has contacted X for comment.

Musk, who has long framed himself as a champion of online free speech, has touted Community Notes as an effective tool to maintain factual discourse on X without resorting to top-down speech guidelines.

“Community Notes aims to help all people better understand issues discussed in posts, including people who may hold different viewpoints,” the company’s website reads. Agency for International Development (USAID), the foreign aid agency that Musk has repeatedly claimed without evidence is a “criminal organization.”

Elon Musk and Donald Trump have claimed in recent days the Ukrainian president is an unpopular ‘dictator,’ despite public polls showing he retains wide support (Reuters)

The sociology institute [has in fact received past support](https://www.kiis.com.ua/?lang=eng&cat=reports&page=2&y=2024&m=2)
 from USAID, an agency Musk’s company Starlink also [once collaborated with in Ukraine](/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-elon-musk-investigations-doge-b2695807.html)
.[](/news/world/europe/ukraine-russia-war-trump-zelensky-dictator-putin-news-b2701322.html)
[](/topic/volodymyr-zelensky)

On Thursday Musk took to the stage with Argentinian president Javier Milei at the Conservative Political Action Conference, where he held up a chainsaw - replicating a previous stunt by Milei to represent the cuts he planned to government spending.

Trump and Musk have been accused of playing into [Russia](/topic/russia)
’s heavily distorted narrative of its invasion of the country. unfortunately lives in this disinformation space.”

Experts, including those at the sociology institute, have found that Zelensky has greater than majority support, with a recent survey finding that 57 percent of Ukrainians trusted the president.

Keith Darden, an American University professor who studies Ukraine, [told](https://www.cnn.com/2025/02/19/politics/fact-check-trump-falsely-claims-zelensky-has-a-4-approval-rating-its-above-50/index.html)
 CNN the private institute is considered “the best and most reliable survey organization in Ukraine,” and its findings are quoted in U.S. “Spreading misinformation about his legitimacy directly aids Kremlin propaganda and undermines the Ukrainian people’s right to determine their own future.”

Zelensky said on Wednesday that claims he’s a dictator are “coming from Russia.”

“If anyone wants to replace me right now, then it just isn’t going to happen,” he [said](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/02/19/ukraine-russia-trump-elections-zelensky/)
 at a news conference. Because none of this is having a positive effect on Ukraine.”

Indeed, Russian leaders have praised the White House, with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov saying that Trump “[understands our position](/news/world/americas/trump-russia-zelensky-ukraine-war-blame-b2701773.html)
.”

“A Dictator without Elections, Zelenskyy better move fast or he is not going to have a Country left.’ If you'd told me just three months ago that these were the words of the US president, I would have laughed out loud,” former Russian president [](https://x.com/MedvedevRussiaE)
[Dmitry Medvedev](https://x.com/MedvedevRussiaE)
 [wrote](https://x.com/MedvedevRussiaE/status/1892289659603910745)
 on X. Bankrupt clown…”

Ukrainian and international leaders expressed their support for Zelensky after the claims from Trump and Musk, and argued the White House is playing into Putin’s hands.

“We may like Zelensky, or we may not. And no lying creature, neither in Moscow, nor in Washington, nor anywhere, has the right to open his mouth against him.”

Former Lithuanian foreign minister Gabrielius Landsbergis [told](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2025/02/19/ukraine-russia-trump-elections-zelensky/)

Following Trump’s comments, UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer [affirmed](https://kyivindependent.com/zelensky-legitimacy-question/)
 his position that Zelensky is the country’s "democratically elected leader,” and argued it is "perfectly reasonable to suspend elections during wartime as the U.K."

Content: "[Americas](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas)
  
  

Elon Musk claims Ukrainian president 'killed an American journalist'
====================================================================

#### Musk's remarks come after Trump labels Zelenskyy a 'dictator'

Merve Aydogan  | 20.02.2025 - Update : 20.02.2025

![Elon Musk claims Ukrainian president 'killed an American journalist'](https://cdnuploads.aa.com.tr/uploads/Contents/2025/02/20/thumbs_b_c_b1f135798dc1d3ee3a394fa1103048b5.jpg?v=013315)  
  

[![](https://cdnassets.aa.com.tr/assets/newVersion/images/next-sosyal-icon.png)](https://sosyal.teknofest.app/share?url=http://v.aa.com.tr/3487351&text=Elon+Musk+claims+Ukrainian+president+%27killed+an+American+journalist%27)

[](#!)

**HAMILTON, Canada**

Billionaire Elon Musk, a senior advisor to US President Donald Trump, accused Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy of killing an American journalist.

"Zelensky killed an American journalist!" Musk said Wednesday on his X account after Trump called the Ukrainian leader a "dictator without elections" and warned that he "better move fast or he is not going to have a Country left."

Musk's post came after an account claimed that Chilean-American journalist Gonzalo Lira was killed in Ukraine last year for allegedly being critical of Zelenskyy.

Trump posted on his Truth Social platform hours after Zelenskyy hit back at his suggestion that Kyiv "should have never started" the war, saying the US president was living in a Russian "disinformation bubble."

Trump has advanced negotiations to end the three-year-long war in Ukraine, without the participation of Kyiv and other European governments.

He said Europe has failed to bring peace to Ukraine and the US was successfully negotiating an end to the war. **Please contact us for subscription options.**](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/p/subscription/1001)

# Your Summary

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 Elon Musk posted on X that he is planning to suspend Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s X account."

## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X post Zelenskyy account February 2025")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy): 
Content: Al Jazeera published an article on February 21, 2025, discussing Elon Musk's criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity. <image:1> Musk stated that Zelenskyy should hold an election and that X's fact-checking tool was being "gamed". The article mentions Musk's comments on X, but it does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account.


From [Source](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html): 
Content: The Independent published an article discussing Elon Musk's accusations against Volodymyr Zelenskyy, including a claim that Zelenskyy is "despised by the people of Ukraine." The article also mentions that Musk vowed to "fix" X's Community Notes feature. The article was published on February 20, 2025. <image:9562>


From [Source](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351): 
Content: The search result from Anadolu Agency, dated February 20, 2025, reports that Elon Musk claimed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy "killed an American journalist" on his X account. <image:k>


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
Al Jazeera published an article on February 21, 2025, discussing Elon Musk's criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity. The article mentions Musk's comments on X, but it does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. ([https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy)) <image:1>

The Independent published an article discussing Elon Musk's accusations against Volodymyr Zelenskyy, including a claim that Zelenskyy is "despised by the people of Ukraine." The article also mentions that Musk vowed to "fix" X's Community Notes feature. The article was published on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html)) <image:9562> Anadolu Agency reported that Elon Musk claimed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy "killed an American journalist" on his X account on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351)) <image:k>

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 Elon Musk posted on X that he is planning to suspend Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s X account."

## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X post Zelenskyy account February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Al Jazeera published an article on February 21, 2025, discussing Elon Musk's criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity. The article mentions Musk's comments on X, but it does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. ([https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy)) <image:1>

The Independent published an article discussing Elon Musk's accusations against Volodymyr Zelenskyy, including a claim that Zelenskyy is "despised by the people of Ukraine." The article also mentions that Musk vowed to "fix" X's Community Notes feature. The article was published on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html)) <image:9562> Anadolu Agency reported that Elon Musk claimed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy "killed an American journalist" on his X account on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351)) <image:k>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence indicates that Elon Musk was actively posting on X about Volodymyr Zelenskyy in February 2025. However, the provided articles do not mention any plans by Musk to suspend Zelenskyy's X account. One article from Anadolu Agency reports that Musk accused Zelenskyy of killing an American journalist. Other articles discuss Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity.

Based on the available evidence, the claim cannot be verified. The search results do not provide any information about Musk planning to suspend Zelenskyy's account.

To verify the claim, information about Musk's specific posts regarding the suspension of Zelenskyy's account is needed.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 Elon Musk posted on X that he is planning to suspend Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s X account."

## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X post Zelenskyy account February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Al Jazeera published an article on February 21, 2025, discussing Elon Musk's criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity. The article mentions Musk's comments on X, but it does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. ([https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy)) <image:1>

The Independent published an article discussing Elon Musk's accusations against Volodymyr Zelenskyy, including a claim that Zelenskyy is "despised by the people of Ukraine." The article also mentions that Musk vowed to "fix" X's Community Notes feature. The article was published on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html)) <image:9562> Anadolu Agency reported that Elon Musk claimed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy "killed an American journalist" on his X account on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351)) <image:k>


## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that Elon Musk was actively posting on X about Volodymyr Zelenskyy in February 2025. However, the provided articles do not mention any plans by Musk to suspend Zelenskyy's X account. One article from Anadolu Agency reports that Musk accused Zelenskyy of killing an American journalist. Other articles discuss Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity.

Based on the available evidence, the claim cannot be verified. The search results do not provide any information about Musk planning to suspend Zelenskyy's account.

To verify the claim, information about Musk's specific posts regarding the suspension of Zelenskyy's account is needed.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results show that Elon Musk was active on X discussing Volodymyr Zelenskyy in February 2025, including accusations against him. However, none of the provided sources mention Musk planning to suspend Zelenskyy's X account.

`not enough information`

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

([https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy)) <image:1>

Other articles discuss Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity.

Based on the available evidence, the claim cannot be verified. The search results do not provide any information about Musk planning to suspend Zelenskyy's account.

To verify the claim, information about Musk's specific posts regarding the suspension of Zelenskyy's account is needed.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 Elon Musk posted on X that he is planning to suspend Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s X account."

## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X post Zelenskyy account February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Al Jazeera published an article on February 21, 2025, discussing Elon Musk's criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity. The article mentions Musk's comments on X, but it does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. ([https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy)) <image:1>

The Independent published an article discussing Elon Musk's accusations against Volodymyr Zelenskyy, including a claim that Zelenskyy is "despised by the people of Ukraine." The article also mentions that Musk vowed to "fix" X's Community Notes feature. The article was published on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html)) <image:9562> Anadolu Agency reported that Elon Musk claimed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy "killed an American journalist" on his X account on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351)) <image:k>

Other articles discuss Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity.

Based on the available evidence, the claim cannot be verified. The search results do not provide any information about Musk planning to suspend Zelenskyy's account.

## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X account suspension Zelenskyy February 2025")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_under_Elon_Musk): 
Content: "Having previously restored [Tommy Robinson](/wiki/Tommy_Robinson_(activist) "Tommy Robinson (activist)")
's account, Musk interacted with him on the platform,[\[55\]](#cite_note-55)
[\[56\]](#cite_note-56)
[\[57\]](#cite_note-BBCAug7GamePlan-57)
[\[58\]](#cite_note-BBCAug8RiotPost-58)
 and went on to refer to Starmer as "two-tier Keir" and ask the protection of communities in Britain.[\[59\]](#cite_note-59)
[\[57\]](#cite_note-BBCAug7GamePlan-57)
 Musk also promoted a conspiracy theory that the UK government was planning to build detainments camps in the [Falkland Islands](/wiki/Falkland_Islands "Falkland Islands")
 to hold rioters.[\[58\]](#cite_note-BBCAug8RiotPost-58)
 The UK's [Secretary of State for Science, Innovation and Technology](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Science,_Innovation_and_Technology "Secretary of State for Science, Innovation and Technology")
 [Peter Kyle](/wiki/Peter_Kyle "Peter Kyle")
 said that in practice dealing with large tech companies and their leaders can be more like negotiating with foreign states than normal businesses.[\[60\]](#cite_note-60)

In December 2024, the X website was redesigned, giving it a more modern and simplified look alongside removing the last elements of the Twitter branding (such as blue colors).[\[61\]](#cite_note-61)
 Musk argued in February 2025 that X's [Community Notes](/wiki/Community_Notes "Community Notes")
 "is increasingly being gamed by governments & legacy media", and that he was taking steps to "fix" it.[\[62\]](#cite_note-Marco-62)
[\[63\]](#cite_note-Vanian-63)
[\[64\]](#cite_note-64)
 The statement came after Community Notes contradicted Musk's claims on astronauts and [legacy media](/wiki/Legacy_media "Legacy media")
, and also contradicted claims that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was unpopular among Ukrainians.[\[62\]](#cite_note-Marco-62)
[\[63\]](#cite_note-Vanian-63)

In 2025 the _[Wall Street Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")
_ reported that Musk had used the platform to solicit an influencer he had never met in person to have his child. 
> You won't find the tweet unless you specifically seek it out, which is no different from rest of Internet.
> 
> November 18, 2022[\[226\]](#cite_note-226)

In December 2022, Twitter dissolved the [Trust and Safety](/wiki/Trust_and_safety "Trust and safety")
 Council responsible for Twitter's policies on hate speech, child sexual exploitation, and self-harm content.[\[227\]](#cite_note-227)
 This occurred while evidence showed an increase in hate speech following Musk's acquisition.[\[228\]](#cite_note-Hickey-2304-228)
 The new head of Trust and Safety, Ella Irwin, announced that Twitter had moved towards more [automation](/wiki/Automation "Automation")
 to moderate content, in order to restrict diffusion,[\[229\]](#cite_note-229)
 later described by Musk as "freedom of speech, not freedom of reach".[\[168\]](#cite_note-Piemontese-20232-168)

Twitter adopted an updated [zero-tolerance](/wiki/Zero-tolerance "Zero-tolerance")
 policy on "violent speech" on February 28, 2023, described by _[The Verge](/wiki/The_Verge "The Verge")
_ as both "more specific _and_ more vague" than the prior version.[\[230\]](#cite_note-230)
[\[231\]](#cite_note-231)
 As of April 2023 there was no evidence of policy changes that had decreased the overall number of bots, although there was some evidence that [spambots](/wiki/Spambot "Spambot")
 had decreased slightly.[\[228\]](#cite_note-Hickey-2304-228)

### Account suspensions and reinstatements

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Account suspensions and reinstatements")\
\]

Main article: [Twitter suspensions](/wiki/Twitter_suspensions "Twitter suspensions")

Within hours of the takeover in October 2022, the far-right [Britain First](/wiki/Britain_First "Britain First")
 account, previously banned in 2017, was reinstated.[\[232\]](#cite_note-232)
[\[233\]](#cite_note-233)
 Account bans continued to be lifted in late November 2022, beginning with [Jordan Peterson](/wiki/Jordan_Peterson "Jordan Peterson")
, [Kathy Griffin](/wiki/Kathy_Griffin "Kathy Griffin")
, _[The Babylon Bee](/wiki/The_Babylon_Bee "The Babylon Bee")
_, and [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")
.[\[234\]](#cite_note-234)
[\[235\]](#cite_note-235)
 Multiple accounts were suspended, many of which had been named by [far-right](/wiki/Far-right "Far-right")
 figures who urged Musk to take action. This decision sparked mixed reactions, with some users protesting by responding to posts they liked with images of the "Yeah!" button from [Nintendo](/wiki/Nintendo "Nintendo")
's discontinued [Miiverse](/wiki/Miiverse "Miiverse")
 social network.[\[332\]](#cite_note-332)
[\[333\]](#cite_note-333)

In October 2024, the "For You" section was found to be highly politicized for new accounts with twice as much pro-Trump content than pro-Harris.[\[334\]](#cite_note-334)
 Twitter also announced that the block function would be changed to allow blocked accounts to view public posts, but not interact with said posts,[\[335\]](#cite_note-335)
 and regardless of consent, posts would be used to train [generative AI](/wiki/Generative_AI "Generative AI")
.[\[336\]](#cite_note-336)

Changes to the algorithm
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Changes to the algorithm")\
\]

### "For You" feed

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: "For You" feed")\
\]

Under Elon Musk, Twitter's "Newsfeed" tab was split into two new tabs: "For You" and "Following".[\[337\]](#cite_note-conger-7apr23-337)
 While the latter, like "Newsfeed", only displays activity from accounts followed by the user, "For You" displays an algorithmically curated feed similar to that of [TikTok](/wiki/TikTok "TikTok")
.[\[337\]](#cite_note-conger-7apr23-337)
 With a paid subscription to [Twitter Blue](/wiki/Twitter_verification "Twitter verification")
, users can have their tweets boosted by this algorithm.[\[337\]](#cite_note-conger-7apr23-337)
 This change was blamed for a rise in disinformation on the platform, with some paying accounts being used to spread fake news, notably pro-Kremlin propaganda related to the [Russo-Ukrainian War](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine")
.[\[172\]](#cite_note-Hammond2023-172)

### Promotion of Elon Musk's tweets

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Promotion of Elon Musk's tweets")\
\]

On February 7, 2023, Elon Musk convened a meeting of Twitter engineers and advisors to address the decline in engagement with his own tweets.[\[338\]](#cite_note-newton-9feb23-338)
 One of the company's two principal engineers, after suggesting that public interest in Musk was waning following a peak during [his acquisition of the platform](/wiki/Acquisition_of_Twitter_by_Elon_Musk "Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk")
, was fired.[\[338\]](#cite_note-newton-9feb23-338)
 A [Google Trends](/wiki/Google_Trends "Google Trends")
 chart presented by employees had shown a decline in popularity.[\[338\]](#cite_note-newton-9feb23-338)
 The following week, after the [Super Bowl LVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LVII "Super Bowl LVII")
, Twitter employee James Musk, who is Elon's paternal cousin, sent a message to the company's engineers concerning a "high urgency" matter: that Elon Musk's tweet about the Super Bowl had received less impressions than one sent by US president [Joe Biden](/wiki/Joe_Biden "Joe Biden")
.[\[339\]](#cite_note-newton-15feb23-339)
 By that afternoon, Twitter's algorithm had been altered to artificially boost Musk's tweets by a factor of 1,000.[\[339\]](#cite_note-newton-15feb23-339)
 Many users observed an overwhelming promotion of his posts in the "For You" tab.[\[339\]](#cite_note-newton-15feb23-339)
 Following criticism, the boost was lessened to a smaller factor.[\[339\]](#cite_note-newton-15feb23-339)

### Promotion of state-controlled media

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Promotion of state-controlled media")\
\]

On April 6, 2023, Twitter reversed its official policy stating that the platform would not "recommend or amplify" the content of state-controlled media entities.[\[173\]](#cite_note-kann-173)
 According to an analysis by the [Digital Forensic Research Lab](/wiki/Digital_Forensic_Research_Lab "Digital Forensic Research Lab")
, the change had already taken effect since around March 29, when Twitter stopped filtering government accounts in [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia")
, [China](/wiki/China "China")
 and [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran")
.[\[173\]](#cite_note-kann-173)
 These accounts, such as those managed by Russia's [RT](/wiki/RT_(TV_network) "RT (TV network)")
, have a significant presence on the platform.[\[173\]](#cite_note-kann-173)
 Following the change, which enabled the accounts to be algorithmically promoted by Twitter, their follower count quickly rose.[\[173\]](#cite_note-kann-173)

### Promotion of conservative content

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Promotion of conservative content")\
\]

A computational analysis published on November 1, 2024, found potential algorithmic bias on Twitter in favour of [Republican Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States) "Republican Party (United States)")
 supporters.[\[340\]](#cite_note-davis-340)
[\[341\]](#cite_note-computational-analysis-341)
 The study, which looked at more than 56,000 posts, identified a system-wide "structural break" on the platform around July 13, 2024, a date which coincides with Elon Musk's endorsement of [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")
 in the [2024 US presidential election](/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election "2024 United States presidential election")
.[\[341\]](#cite_note-computational-analysis-341)
 From that point on, Elon Musk and other Republican commentators saw increased visibility for their tweets.[\[341\]](#cite_note-computational-analysis-341)
 According to the researchers behind the study, this "could imply an algorithmic adjustment".[\[341\]](#cite_note-computational-analysis-341)
 On January 17, 2025, the [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission")
 requested to see Twitter's internal documentation about its algorithms "and any recent changes made to it", following accusations of manipulation benefitting [far-right](/wiki/Far-right_politics "Far-right politics")
 viewpoints.[\[342\]](#cite_note-guardian-dsa-jan17-342)

Major developments
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Major developments")\
\]

### Verification

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Verification")\
\]

Further information: [Twitter verification § Since November 2022](/wiki/Twitter_verification#Since_November_2022 "Twitter verification")

[![Gold-colored eight-lobed badge with checkmark icon](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Twitter_Verified_Badge_Gold.svg/250px-Twitter_Verified_Badge_Gold.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Twitter_Verified_Badge_Gold.svg)

Badge for verified organizations

[![Gray eight-lobed badge with checkmark icon](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Twitter_Verified_Badge_Gray.svg/250px-Twitter_Verified_Badge_Gray.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Twitter_Verified_Badge_Gray.svg)

Badge for government accounts

On November 5, 2022,[\[343\]](#cite_note-343)
 Twitter required users to purchase a [Twitter Blue](/wiki/Twitter_Blue "Twitter Blue")
 subscription to indicate they were "[verified](/wiki/Twitter_verification "Twitter verification")
" on the platform,[\[344\]](#cite_note-344)
[\[345\]](#cite_note-345)
 which was then delayed until after the [U.S. [Jump to content](#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

[Elon Musk](/wiki/Elon_Musk "Elon Musk")
 completed [the acquisition of Twitter](/wiki/Acquisition_of_Twitter_by_Elon_Musk "Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk")
 in October 2022; Musk acted as [CEO](/wiki/Chief_executive_officer "Chief executive officer")
 of [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter")
 until June 2023 when he was succeeded by [Linda Yaccarino](/wiki/Linda_Yaccarino "Linda Yaccarino")
.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)
[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)
 Twitter was rebranded to X on July 23, 2023,[\[3\]](#cite_note-rebrand-3)
 and its domain name changed from twitter.com to x.com on May 17, 2024.[\[4\]](#cite_note-url-4)
 Yaccarino resigned on July 9, 2025.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

Now operating as X, the platform closely resembles its predecessor but includes additional features such as long-form texts,[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)
 account monetization options,[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)
 audio-video calls,[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)
 integration with [xAI](/wiki/XAI_(company) "XAI (company)")
's [Grok](/wiki/Grok_(chatbot) "Grok (chatbot)")
 chatbot,[\[9\]](#cite_note-The_Indian_Express-2023-9)
 job search,[\[10\]](#cite_note-HR_Dive-10)
 and a [repurposing of the platform's verification system as a subscription premium](/wiki/Twitter_Blue_verification_controversy "Twitter Blue verification controversy")
.[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)
 Several legacy Twitter features were removed from the site after Musk acquired Twitter, including Circles,[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)
 [NFT](/wiki/Non-fungible_token "Non-fungible token")
 profile pictures,[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)
 and the experimental [pronouns](/wiki/Preferred_gender_pronoun "Preferred gender pronoun")
 in profiles feature.[\[14\]](#cite_note-14)
 Musk aims to transform X into an "everything app", akin to [WeChat](/wiki/WeChat "WeChat")
.[\[15\]](#cite_note-Ortutay-2023-15)

X has faced significant controversy post-rebranding. I will abide by the results of this poll.
> 
> |     |     |     |
> | --- | --- | --- |
> |     |     |     |     |     |
> | Yes |     |     | 57.5% |     |
> | No  |     |     | 42.5% |     |
> | 17,502,391 votes · Final results |     |     |     |     |
> 
> December 18, 2022[\[103\]](#cite_note-103)
> [\[104\]](#cite_note-104)

On November 16, 2022, Musk stated that he planned to eventually appoint a new CEO to oversee Twitter,[\[105\]](#cite_note-105)
 shortly thereafter beginning the process of searching for his successor.[\[106\]](#cite_note-106)
 On December 18, amid growing public discontent surrounding the [ElonJet](/wiki/ElonJet "ElonJet")
 and [Mastodon](/wiki/Mastodon_(social_network) "Mastodon (social network)")
 controversies, Musk conducted an [open-access](/wiki/Open-access_poll "Open-access poll")
 Twitter poll asking whether he should resign from his position as Twitter CEO, claiming that he would "abide by the results".[\[107\]](#cite_note-107)
[\[108\]](#cite_note-108)
 The poll resolved to "yes" after 57.5 percent of 17.5 million users voted in favor of him stepping down.[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)
[\[110\]](#cite_note-110)

After this result, Musk responded "interesting" to unfounded theories that the result of the resignation poll had been influenced by bots, agreeing with a user's suggestion to restrict future polls on policy changes to paid Twitter Blue subscribers.[\[111\]](#cite_note-111)
[\[112\]](#cite_note-112)
[\[113\]](#cite_note-113)
 On December 20, he announced he would step down as CEO as soon as his replacement was selected, but would continue to lead Twitter's software and server teams.[\[114\]](#cite_note-114)
 On April 11, 2023, he told the BBC that he had stepped down and appointed his dog as CEO.[\[115\]](#cite_note-115)

On May 11, 2023, Musk announced he had found a person to succeed him in the CEO position;[\[116\]](#cite_note-GuardianCEO-116)
 the following day, he named [Linda Yaccarino](/wiki/Linda_Yaccarino "Linda Yaccarino")
, former head of ad sales for [NBCUniversal](/wiki/NBCUniversal "NBCUniversal")
, to succeed him as CEO.[\[117\]](#cite_note-VarietyCEO-117)

### Corporate value

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Corporate value")\
\]

One year after the Musk acquisition, company documents related to employee [restricted stock](/wiki/Restricted_stock "Restricted stock")
 grants showed the company had estimated its own valuation at about $19 billion, down about 55% from Musk's purchase price.[\[118\]](#cite_note-118)
[\[119\]](#cite_note-119)
 A lower estimate was reported in October 2023 from [Fidelity](/wiki/Fidelity_Investments "Fidelity Investments")
 at about the same time, estimating the company to be down 65% from its purchase price.[\[120\]](#cite_note-120)
 Fidelity estimated in October 2024 that the company's value was down 79% from Musk's original purchase price, 24% lower than what Fidelity had estimated two months earlier.[\[121\]](#cite_note-121)
 In February 2025, Musk was reportedly in talks for a new round of financing at a $44 billion valuation, thus returning to the valuation at the time of purchase.[\[122\]](#cite_note-122)

### Fines

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Fines")\
\]

In August 2023, X was fined US$350,000 for failing to meet two deadlines to comply with a [U.S. The Full Access plan, priced at $1,000 per month or $10,000 per year, includes all the Basic plan features plus increased reach, affiliations, and a limited-time advertising credit of $12,000 per year or $1,000 per month.[\[155\]](#cite_note-155)
[\[156\]](#cite_note-156)

### X Money Account

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: X Money Account")\
\]

In January 2025, X announced plans to introduce an "X Money Account" feature later in the year.[\[157\]](#cite_note-157)
 The feature which would function as a digital wallet allowing real-time payments on the social media platform and moving funds to and from traditional bank accounts.[\[158\]](#cite_note-158)
 [Visa](/wiki/Visa_Inc. 
> No major content decisions or account reinstatements will happen before that council convenes.
> 
> October 28, 2022[\[160\]](#cite_note-160)

### Initial reforms

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Initial reforms")\
\]

On October 28, 2022, Musk announced that a "content moderation council" with diversified viewpoints would be established to inform the platform's "content policy", and declared a moratorium in "major content decisions or account reinstatements" until then.[\[161\]](#cite_note-161)
 The council was never formed; Musk claimed that it had been part of a deal made with activists who had failed to honor it.[\[162\]](#cite_note-162)
 He also signaled an intention to do away with lifetime account [suspensions](/wiki/Twitter_suspensions "Twitter suspensions")
 and unban those suspended for "minor \[or\] dubious reasons".[\[163\]](#cite_note-163)
[\[164\]](#cite_note-164)
[\[165\]](#cite_note-165)
 Musk later stated that he would not alter Twitter's content policies or restore banned accounts until after the [midterm elections](/wiki/2022_United_States_midterm_elections "2022 United States midterm elections")
.[\[166\]](#cite_note-166)
[\[167\]](#cite_note-167)

In June 2023, Musk defended the approach to content moderation as "[freedom of speech](/wiki/Freedom_of_speech "Freedom of speech")
, not freedom of reach", but went against his own policies, restricting the use of the terms "cis" and "cisgender" arguing that they are slurs,[\[168\]](#cite_note-Piemontese-20232-168)
 and describing the platform as having [liberal bias](/wiki/Liberal_bias "Liberal bias")
.[\[169\]](#cite_note-169)
 In September 2023, X subsequently scrapped the feature for users to report misleading posts, instead relying exclusively on [Community Notes](/wiki/Community_Notes "Community Notes")
 to combat misinformation on the platform.[\[170\]](#cite_note-Taylor-2023-170)

### Handling of misinformation and disinformation

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Handling of misinformation and disinformation")\
\]

Further information: [Community Notes § Criticisms and analysis](/wiki/Community_Notes#Criticisms_and_analysis "Community Notes")

In November 2022, X announced it would no longer enforce its policy prohibiting [COVID-19 misinformation](/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation "COVID-19 misinformation")
.[\[171\]](#cite_note-171)
 Algorithm changes promoted viral [disinformation about the Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Disinformation_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Disinformation in the Russian invasion of Ukraine")
, and led to significant gains in followers for media outlets affiliated with Russia, China and Iran.[\[172\]](#cite_note-Hammond2023-172)
[\[173\]](#cite_note-kann-173)
 Twitter, like Meta, Twitch, and Alphabet, laid off a significant portion of its content moderators in 2023.[\[174\]](#cite_note-174)

As of September 2023, Twitter relied exclusively on its _[Community Notes](/wiki/Community_Notes "Community Notes")
_ program to combat misinformation,[\[170\]](#cite_note-Taylor-2023-170)
 leading to failures in labeling misinformation.[\[175\]](#cite_note-Weatherbed-2023-175)
[\[176\]](#cite_note-Spangler-2023-176)
[\[177\]](#cite_note-NewsGuard-2023-177)
 The program has become responsible for spreading misinformation[\[178\]](#cite_note-178)
[\[179\]](#cite_note-179)
[\[180\]](#cite_note-180)
 as well as delays in fact-checking.[\[181\]](#cite_note-181)
 A [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission")
 study found that disinformation was most prevalent and received the highest relative engagement on Twitter, compared to other major social networks,[\[182\]](#cite_note-Goswami-2023-182)
[\[183\]](#cite_note-183)
 leading to warnings of a potential ban or fines by the EU for non-compliance with the [Digital Services Act](/wiki/Digital_Services_Act "Digital Services Act")
.[\[184\]](#cite_note-184)
[\[185\]](#cite_note-185)

In October 2023, media outlets and experts observed significant [disinformation related to the war in Gaza](/wiki/Misinformation_in_the_Gaza_war "Misinformation in the Gaza war")
.[\[186\]](#cite_note-Milmo-2023-186)
[\[182\]](#cite_note-Goswami-2023-182)
[\[187\]](#cite_note-187)
 A BBC journalist described a "deluge" of false information, including by "blue tick" accounts,[\[186\]](#cite_note-Milmo-2023-186)
 and CNBC found that while some videos were flagged as "misleading or false", identical re-posts remained unflagged. A spokesperson for the European Commission confirmed that X is affected by the EU rules, and has advised European institutions to abstain from advertising on the platform.[\[209\]](#cite_note-209)

Following the [Dublin riots](/wiki/2023_Dublin_riot "2023 Dublin riot")
 in [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland")
 on November 23, X faced criticism for allowing "vile messages" on the platform, described as hate speech, while other social media platforms, [TikTok](/wiki/TikTok "TikTok")
, [Instagram](/wiki/Instagram "Instagram")
, and [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook")
, complied with [Garda](/wiki/Garda_S%C3%ADoch%C3%A1na "Garda Síochána")
 requests for taking down content.[\[210\]](#cite_note-210)
[\[211\]](#cite_note-211)
 After Prime Minister [Leo Varadkar](/wiki/Leo_Varadkar "Leo Varadkar")
 called for incitement to hatred legislation to be updated, Musk responded by stating "the Irish PM hates the Irish people".[\[212\]](#cite_note-212)
[\[213\]](#cite_note-213)

### Child sexual abuse material

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Child sexual abuse material")\
\]

In August 2023, it was reported that [child sexual abuse material](/wiki/Child_sexual_abuse_material "Child sexual abuse material")
 (CSAM) on Twitter was still an issue, despite statements by Musk that removing it was a top priority.[\[214\]](#cite_note-NYT_CP-214)
[\[215\]](#cite_note-Vice_CP-215)
 As of June 2023, an investigation by the [Stanford Internet Observatory](/wiki/Stanford_Internet_Observatory "Stanford Internet Observatory")
 at [Stanford University](/wiki/Stanford_University "Stanford University")
 reported "a lapse in basic enforcement" against CSAM by Twitter within "recent months".[\[216\]](#cite_note-216)
[\[217\]](#cite_note-217)
 The number of staff on Twitter's trust and safety teams were reduced, for example, leaving one full-time staffer to handle all child sexual abuse material in the [Asia-Pacific](/wiki/Asia-Pacific "Asia-Pacific")
 region in November 2022.[\[218\]](#cite_note-218)
[\[219\]](#cite_note-WP_CP-219)
[\[220\]](#cite_note-220)
 A 2023 investigation by _[BBC Panorama](/wiki/BBC_Panorama "BBC Panorama")
_ found concerns that child sexual abuse was rising, following the layoffs and changes at Twitter since Musk's takeover.[\[199\]](#cite_note-Spring2023-199)

According to the _[Australian Financial Review](/wiki/Australian_Financial_Review "Australian Financial Review")
_, the Australian government's eSafety Commission reported in March 2023 that, since Musk's acquisition of the platform, "the proactive detection of child sexual exploitation material \[on Twitter\] fell from 90 per cent to 75 per cent."[\[221\]](#cite_note-:3-221)
 In 2024, the company unsuccessfully attempted to avoid the imposition of fines in Australia regarding the government's inquiries about child safety enforcement; X Corp reportedly said they had no obligation to respond to the inquiries since they were addressed to "Twitter Inc", which X Corp argued had "ceased to exist".[\[221\]](#cite_note-:3-221)
[\[222\]](#cite_note-222)

Elon Musk was criticized in July 2023 for intervening to unban political influencer "Dom Lucre".[\[223\]](#cite_note-:2-223)
[\[219\]](#cite_note-WP_CP-219)
 Lucre had, according to _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")
_, "posted a screenshot of a video depicting child sexual abuse on July 22 reportedly connected to [Peter Scully](/wiki/Peter_Scully "Peter Scully")
, an Australian man sentenced to [life in prison](/wiki/Life_in_prison "Life in prison")
 for sexually abusing children as young as 18 months, whose video was reportedly created on the [dark web](/wiki/Dark_web "Dark web")
."[\[223\]](#cite_note-:2-223)
 _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")
_ reported that the Twitter post by Lucre was viewed 3 million times, and was "an image of a toddler being [tortured](/wiki/Tortured "Tortured")
."[\[219\]](#cite_note-WP_CP-219)
 Musk stated the platform would "delete those posts and reinstate the account."[\[223\]](#cite_note-:2-223)

In June 2025, [NBC](/wiki/NBC_News "NBC News")
 reported about the status of child protection on Twitter under Elon Musk as of that date. Among those banned include a group that provided security to [LGBTQ+](/wiki/LGBTQ%2B "LGBTQ+")
 events, and several accounts parodying Musk.[\[236\]](#cite_note-236)
[\[237\]](#cite_note-237)
 Twitter has also suspended the accounts of Musk/Tesla critic [Aaron Greenspan](/wiki/Aaron_Greenspan "Aaron Greenspan")
 and his legal transparency company [PlainSite](/wiki/PlainSite "PlainSite")
,[\[238\]](#cite_note-238)
 and several journalists and left-leaning accounts, including [Ken Klippenstein](/wiki/Ken_Klippenstein "Ken Klippenstein")
.[\[239\]](#cite_note-239)

In November, Twitter analytics firm [Bot Sentinel](/wiki/Bot_Sentinel "Bot Sentinel")
 calculated that around 877,000 accounts were deactivated and 497,000 were suspended between October 28 and November 1, over double the usual number.[\[240\]](#cite_note-240)
[\[241\]](#cite_note-241)
 In December, neo-Nazi and founder of _[The Daily Stormer](/wiki/The_Daily_Stormer "The Daily Stormer")
_ [Andrew Anglin](/wiki/Andrew_Anglin "Andrew Anglin")
 was reinstated,[\[242\]](#cite_note-242)
 within 24 hours of [Kanye West](/wiki/Kanye_West "Kanye West")
's suspension after posting an antisemitic tweet.[\[243\]](#cite_note-243)
 with his account later restored in July 2023.[\[244\]](#cite_note-244)
[\[245\]](#cite_note-245)

In August 2024, a [Brazilian Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Federal_Court "Supreme Federal Court")
 judge cautioned that X might face suspension if Musk did not appoint a new legal representative for Brazil within 24 hours, in relation to [issues over the reinstatement of Brazilian accounts](/wiki/Brazilian_investigation_into_Elon_Musk "Brazilian investigation into Elon Musk")
 that had been suspended under a court order. The with platform suspended in late August temporarily,[\[246\]](#cite_note-246)
 the platform blocked the accounts as requested in October.[\[247\]](#cite_note-247)

#### ElonJet and journalists suspended

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Twitter_under_Elon_Musk&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: ElonJet and journalists suspended")\
\]

Main article: [December 2022 Twitter suspensions](/wiki/December_2022_Twitter_suspensions "December 2022 Twitter suspensions")

> |     |     |
> | --- | --- |
> | [![Avatar of Elon Musk](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Elon_Musk_Royal_Society_%28crop2%29.jpg/40px-Elon_Musk_Royal_Society_%28crop2%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Elon_Musk_Royal_Society_(crop2).jpg "Avatar of Elon Musk")<br><br>Avatar of Elon Musk [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Twitter_Verified_Badge.svg/20px-Twitter_Verified_Badge.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Twitter_Verified_Badge.svg) | **Elon Musk [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Twitter_Verified_Badge.svg/20px-Twitter_Verified_Badge.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Twitter_Verified_Badge.svg)** <br><br>@elonmusk |

> Any account doxxing real-time location info of anyone will be suspended, as it is a physical safety violation."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result is from Wikipedia and discusses changes and controversies on X (formerly Twitter) under Elon Musk's ownership. It mentions Musk's statements about fixing the Community Notes feature in February 2025, and his criticism of Zelenskyy. The article also covers account suspensions and reinstatements, including those of far-right figures and journalists. It also mentions the introduction of an "X Money Account" in January 2025. The article does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account.

_________________________



DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 Elon Musk posted on X that he is planning to suspend Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s X account."

## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X post Zelenskyy account February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Al Jazeera published an article on February 21, 2025, discussing Elon Musk's criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity. The article mentions Musk's comments on X, but it does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. ([https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy)) <image:1>

The Independent published an article discussing Elon Musk's accusations against Volodymyr Zelenskyy, including a claim that Zelenskyy is "despised by the people of Ukraine." The article also mentions that Musk vowed to "fix" X's Community Notes feature. The article was published on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html)) <image:9562> Anadolu Agency reported that Elon Musk claimed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy "killed an American journalist" on his X account on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351)) <image:k>


## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that Elon Musk was actively posting on X about Volodymyr Zelenskyy in February 2025. However, the provided articles do not mention any plans by Musk to suspend Zelenskyy's X account. One article from Anadolu Agency reports that Musk accused Zelenskyy of killing an American journalist. Other articles discuss Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity.

Based on the available evidence, the claim cannot be verified. The search results do not provide any information about Musk planning to suspend Zelenskyy's account.

To verify the claim, information about Musk's specific posts regarding the suspension of Zelenskyy's account is needed.


## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X account suspension Zelenskyy February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_under_Elon_Musk): 
Content: The search result is from Wikipedia and discusses changes and controversies on X (formerly Twitter) under Elon Musk's ownership. It mentions Musk's statements about fixing the Community Notes feature in February 2025, and his criticism of Zelenskyy. The article also covers account suspensions and reinstatements, including those of far-right figures and journalists. It also mentions the introduction of an "X Money Account" in January 2025. The article does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The new evidence, a Wikipedia article about Twitter under Elon Musk, does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. The article discusses Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and account suspensions in general, but it does not provide any information to support the claim.

The claim remains unverified.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 Elon Musk posted on X that he is planning to suspend Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s X account."

## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X post Zelenskyy account February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Al Jazeera published an article on February 21, 2025, discussing Elon Musk's criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity. The article mentions Musk's comments on X, but it does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. ([https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy)) <image:1>

The Independent published an article discussing Elon Musk's accusations against Volodymyr Zelenskyy, including a claim that Zelenskyy is "despised by the people of Ukraine." The article also mentions that Musk vowed to "fix" X's Community Notes feature. The article was published on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html)) <image:9562> Anadolu Agency reported that Elon Musk claimed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy "killed an American journalist" on his X account on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351)) <image:k>


## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that Elon Musk was actively posting on X about Volodymyr Zelenskyy in February 2025. However, the provided articles do not mention any plans by Musk to suspend Zelenskyy's X account. One article from Anadolu Agency reports that Musk accused Zelenskyy of killing an American journalist. Other articles discuss Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity.

Based on the available evidence, the claim cannot be verified. The search results do not provide any information about Musk planning to suspend Zelenskyy's account.

To verify the claim, information about Musk's specific posts regarding the suspension of Zelenskyy's account is needed.


## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X account suspension Zelenskyy February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_under_Elon_Musk): 
Content: The search result is from Wikipedia and discusses changes and controversies on X (formerly Twitter) under Elon Musk's ownership. It mentions Musk's statements about fixing the Community Notes feature in February 2025, and his criticism of Zelenskyy. The article also covers account suspensions and reinstatements, including those of far-right figures and journalists. It also mentions the introduction of an "X Money Account" in January 2025. The article does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account.


## Elaboration
The new evidence, a Wikipedia article about Twitter under Elon Musk, does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. The article discusses Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and account suspensions in general, but it does not provide any information to support the claim.

The claim remains unverified.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results show that Elon Musk was critical of Volodymyr Zelenskyy on X in February 2025. However, there is no evidence in the provided sources to support the claim that Musk planned to suspend Zelenskyy's X account.

`false`

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 Elon Musk posted on X that he is planning to suspend Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s X account."

## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X post Zelenskyy account February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Al Jazeera published an article on February 21, 2025, discussing Elon Musk's criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity. The article mentions Musk's comments on X, but it does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. ([https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy](https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2025/2/21/musk-vows-to-fix-x-after-polls-show-high-support-for-ukraines-zelenskyy)) <image:1>

The Independent published an article discussing Elon Musk's accusations against Volodymyr Zelenskyy, including a claim that Zelenskyy is "despised by the people of Ukraine." The article also mentions that Musk vowed to "fix" X's Community Notes feature. The article was published on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/elon-musk-x-ukraine-trump-zelensky-b2702216.html)) <image:9562> Anadolu Agency reported that Elon Musk claimed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy "killed an American journalist" on his X account on February 20, 2025. ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/elon-musk-claims-ukrainian-president-killed-an-american-journalist/3487351)) <image:k>


## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that Elon Musk was actively posting on X about Volodymyr Zelenskyy in February 2025. However, the provided articles do not mention any plans by Musk to suspend Zelenskyy's X account. One article from Anadolu Agency reports that Musk accused Zelenskyy of killing an American journalist. Other articles discuss Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and his claims about the Ukrainian leader's popularity.

Based on the available evidence, the claim cannot be verified. The search results do not provide any information about Musk planning to suspend Zelenskyy's account.

To verify the claim, information about Musk's specific posts regarding the suspension of Zelenskyy's account is needed.


## Actions
```
web_search("Elon Musk X account suspension Zelenskyy February 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter_under_Elon_Musk): 
Content: The search result is from Wikipedia and discusses changes and controversies on X (formerly Twitter) under Elon Musk's ownership. It mentions Musk's statements about fixing the Community Notes feature in February 2025, and his criticism of Zelenskyy. The article also covers account suspensions and reinstatements, including those of far-right figures and journalists. It also mentions the introduction of an "X Money Account" in January 2025. The article does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account.


## Elaboration
The new evidence, a Wikipedia article about Twitter under Elon Musk, does not mention any plans to suspend Zelenskyy's account. The article discusses Musk's criticism of Zelenskyy and account suspensions in general, but it does not provide any information to support the claim.

The claim remains unverified.


## Final Judgement
The search results show that Elon Musk was critical of Volodymyr Zelenskyy on X in February 2025. However, there is no evidence in the provided sources to support the claim that Musk planned to suspend Zelenskyy's X account.

`false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The fact-check reveals that while Elon Musk was actively posting about Volodymyr Zelenskyy on X in February 2025, there is no evidence from sources like Al Jazeera, The Independent, Anadolu Agency, or Wikipedia to support the claim that Musk planned to suspend Zelenskyy's X account.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russian President Vladimir Putin has died in an explosion in one of his limousines."

## Actions
```
web_search("Vladimir Putin death explosion limousine")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846): 
Content: "Inconsistencies may occur.

✖

A limousine said to be part of [Vladimir Putin](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/vladimir-putin)
's presidential fleet has been gutted by fire.

Social-media users viewed the viral footage of the burning Aurus Senat car, which is believed to be worth around $350,000. The incident took place near the headquarters of Russia's main intelligence agency, the FSB, according to reports.

_Newsweek_ has contacted the Kremlin for comment.

!Vladimir Putin and limousine <image:9718>

File photo: Vladimir Putin exits his Aurus Senat limousine at Red Square in Moscow, Russia, on November 4 2024. File photo: Vladimir Putin exits his Aurus Senat limousine at Red Square in Moscow, Russia, on November 4 2024. Putin reportedly ordered the sewers in the area and his own security staff to be checked.

There were no reports of injuries and no details about the cause of the fire, according to German outlet _Bild._ The story of the incident was also widely picked up by media outlets including those in Ukraine.

The German newspaper said that the incident had caused panic in the Kremlin, noting that security is tight around the Russian president when he travels.

> BREAKING: A luxury limousine from Vladimir Putin’s official motorcade has reportedly exploded just blocks from FSB headquarters in Moscow. You can get in touch with Brendan by emailing b.cole@newsweek.com or follow on him on his X account @brendanmarkcole.

Newsweek AI is in beta. The cause of the fire is not known, and it is not clear whether the vehicle had been personally used by Putin, but the Russian leader has reportedly displayed paranoia about assassination plots.

What To Know
------------

The Aurus limousine blew up on Sretenka Street just north of the FSB headquarters in Lubyanka on Saturday night, with video footage showing the fire spreading to the vehicle's interior.

Onlookers can be seen watching back smoke billowing out of the front of the destroyed vehicle, and the rear of the car also seemed to be damaged.

It is not clear who was using the car, but it is said to be owned by Putin's Presidential Property Management Department, British newspaper _The Sun_ reported. The independent Russian language outlet Meduza [said that Putin](https://www.newsweek.com/putin-decries-massive-blunder-after-top-general-assassinated-2003548)
 had called the incident a major security lapse.

Video from Putin's visit last week to the Arctic city of Murmansk showed servicemen from a ceremonial guard being patted down for hidden weapons or explosive devices before the president came to lay a wreath by the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

What People Are Saying
----------------------

**_The Sun_ newspaper wrote:** "An Aurus limousine from Putin's 'official car fleet' blew up in a huge blast on a street just north of Moscow's FSB secret service headquarters in Lubyanka."

**Ukrainian X user Devana posted:** "Not just Russia is burning—even Putin's limo went boom. So hey, Vladimir—if even your car goes up in flames next to FSB HQ … maybe the system's cracking from within?"

What Happens Next
-----------------

Official comment about the car blast is unlikely, but security around Putin will continue to dominate headlines. [Russia's special services have ramped up](https://www.newsweek.com/putin-spending-personal-security-russia-ukraine-arrest-warrant-icc-1803885)
 the [already-strict security measures](https://www.newsweek.com/putin-bulletproof-vest-armor-public-events-security-1908361)
 surrounding the Russian leader to an unprecedented degree, unnamed Russian and Kremlin officials told _The Moscow Times_ in June 2024.

Comment

Synopsis

A luxury limousine from Russian President Vladimir Putin’s official car fleet exploded in central Moscow, raising security concerns. Increasing speculation surrounds internal threats within the Kremlin and security measures for Putin, including body searches and visible guards inspecting the area.

![Putin](https://img.etimg.com/thumb/msid-119759167,width-300,height-225,imgsize-37638,resizemode-75/putin.jpg)AP

Russian President Vladimir Putin

One of the luxury limousine's from Russian President Vladmir Putin's official car fleet exploded in central Moscow, The Sun reported.
