Enter search text:

Find this comment offensive?

Choose your reason below and click on the Report button. 

  
The explosion happened only days after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky suggested that Russia could suffer a major setback in the war and amid rumors surrounding Putin’s health, according to The Sun. 

  
Zelensky had also stated, “Vladimir Putin will die soon,” calling it a “fact,” as per a report by The Mirror. 

  
The limousine is reportedly managed by the Presidential Property Department, responsible for Putin’s transport. 

  
The explosion comes at a time of increased speculation about threats within Putin’s inner circle. 
  
A video of the burning limousine has gone viral on social media. 
  

> — BRICSinfo (@BRICSinfo)[](https://twitter.com/BRICSinfo/status/1906066537368445191)

  

!ET logo <image:9728>

### Live Events

The [Aurus Senat limousine](/topic/aurus-senat-limousine)
 worth 275,000 Euros is a highlight of Russia’s political elite. The exact cause of the explosion is not known yet and there have been no injuries reported so far, The Sun stated."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Economic Times published an article on March 30, 2025, reporting that one of Vladimir Putin's official limousines exploded in central Moscow, raising security concerns. <image:9727>, <image:9728>. The Sun reported that the explosion happened days after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky suggested that Russia could suffer a major setback in the war and amid rumors surrounding Putin’s health. The article also mentions a video of the burning limousine that went viral on social media.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russian President Vladimir Putin has died in an explosion in one of his limousines."

## Actions
```
web_search("Vladimir Putin death explosion limousine")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow): 
Content: "[](/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow)

[](/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow)
![](https://uawmedia.uawire.org/media/Default/_Profiles/e2c975c6/ea986bf8/Putin_Limo_burns.PNG?v=638789458730000000)

In a dramatic scene near Moscow's FSB headquarters on Lubyanka Street, one of Russian President Vladimir Putin's luxury limousines exploded and caught fire, reports the Serbian news outlet [Kurir](https://www.kurir.rs/planeta/9627201/eksplodirala-putinova-limuzina-aurus-senat-u-moskvi)
.

The blaze, which started in the engine of the €330,000 special-purpose "Aurus Senat" vehicle, rapidly advanced into the interior. Fortunately, no casualties were recorded, although initial reports suggested someone might have been inside at the time.

Known for his preference for domestically produced vehicles, President Putin recently gifted a similar limousine to North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. Officers painstakingly searched all manhole covers and trash bins near a location where Putin intended to speak in Moscow.

On February 3 explosion rocked a luxury apartment complex, "Scarlet Sails," in Moscow. The blast caused Sarkisyan's leg amputation, and according to [Russian media](https://ura.news/news/1052883866)
, he succumbed shortly in intensive care without regaining consciousness, with shrapnel wounds near the heart cited as the preliminary cause of death.

  [Putin](/Tags/Putin)
, [Moscow](/Tags/Moscow)

Comments
--------

* * * Additional footage from a different angle shows damage to the vehicle's rear section as well.

According to reports, the limousine is managed by the Russian President's asset management department. The incident coincides with heightened "paranoia over potential assassination attempts" surrounding the Russian leader.

A troubling recent incident during Putin's visit to Murmansk highlights these security concerns. A video surfaced showing a ceremonial Russian guard undergoing a humiliating process: each soldier was thoroughly searched by an officer from the Federal Protective Service for concealed weapons or explosives before Putin laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Reportedly, the honor guard was issued rifles with no ammunition due to fears of an assassination, possibly even from within Putin's own security.

Security around Putin continues to dominate headlines, as evidenced by another recent case reflecting the Kremlin's "profound concern" for Putin's safety. He was known as Arman Gorlovsky and faced international warrant for assassination-related charges.

As [Kommersant](https://t.me/kommersant/78064)
 explains, the bomb detonated as Sarkisyan and his guards entered the building, resulting in a guard's death and injuries to others."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
UAWire reports that one of Vladimir Putin's luxury limousines exploded and caught fire near Moscow's FSB headquarters. <image:k> The fire started in the engine of the "Aurus Senat" vehicle. No casualties were recorded. The incident coincides with heightened "paranoia over potential assassination attempts" surrounding the Russian leader.

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russian President Vladimir Putin has died in an explosion in one of his limousines."

## Actions
```
web_search("Vladimir Putin death explosion limousine")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846): 
Content: Newsweek reports that a limousine from Vladimir Putin's motorcade caught fire near the FSB headquarters in Moscow. <image:9718>. The cause of the fire is unknown, and there were no reports of injuries. The article mentions that Putin has reportedly displayed paranoia about assassination plots. The article was written by Brendan Cole, a Senior News Reporter.


From [Source](https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms): 
Content: The Economic Times published an article on March 30, 2025, reporting that one of Vladimir Putin's official limousines exploded in central Moscow, raising security concerns. <image:9727>, <image:9728>. The Sun reported that the explosion happened days after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky suggested that Russia could suffer a major setback in the war and amid rumors surrounding Putin’s health. The article also mentions a video of the burning limousine that went viral on social media.


From [Source](https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow): 
Content: UAWire reports that one of Vladimir Putin's luxury limousines exploded and caught fire near Moscow's FSB headquarters. <image:k> The fire started in the engine of the "Aurus Senat" vehicle. No casualties were recorded. The incident coincides with heightened "paranoia over potential assassination attempts" surrounding the Russian leader.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
Newsweek reports that a limousine from Vladimir Putin's motorcade caught fire near the FSB headquarters in Moscow (<image:9718>), with the cause of the fire unknown and no reported injuries. The article mentions Putin's reported paranoia about assassination plots. ([https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846](https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846))

The Economic Times reported that one of Putin's official limousines exploded in central Moscow, raising security concerns (<image:9727>, <image:9728>). The Sun reported that the explosion happened days after Zelensky's statement and amid rumors about Putin's health. ([https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms](https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms)) UAWire reports that one of Putin's luxury limousines exploded and caught fire near Moscow's FSB headquarters (<image:k>), with the fire starting in the engine of the "Aurus Senat" vehicle and no casualties recorded. ([https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow](https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow))

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russian President Vladimir Putin has died in an explosion in one of his limousines."

## Actions
```
web_search("Vladimir Putin death explosion limousine")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Newsweek reports that a limousine from Vladimir Putin's motorcade caught fire near the FSB headquarters in Moscow (<image:9718>), with the cause of the fire unknown and no reported injuries. The article mentions Putin's reported paranoia about assassination plots. ([https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846](https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846))

The Economic Times reported that one of Putin's official limousines exploded in central Moscow, raising security concerns (<image:9727>, <image:9728>). The Sun reported that the explosion happened days after Zelensky's statement and amid rumors about Putin's health. ([https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms](https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms)) UAWire reports that one of Putin's luxury limousines exploded and caught fire near Moscow's FSB headquarters (<image:k>), with the fire starting in the engine of the "Aurus Senat" vehicle and no casualties recorded. ([https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow](https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow))


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence suggests that one of Vladimir Putin's limousines was involved in an incident. Newsweek reports a fire, while The Economic Times and UAWire report an explosion. However, none of the reports confirm the death of Vladimir Putin. The reports mention security concerns and rumors about Putin's health, but they do not provide any information to support the claim that Putin died in an explosion.

The evidence indicates that an incident occurred involving one of Putin's limousines, but it does not confirm the claim that Putin died in an explosion.

To verify the claim, information is missing about Putin's presence in the vehicle during the incident and whether he was harmed.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russian President Vladimir Putin has died in an explosion in one of his limousines."

## Actions
```
web_search("Vladimir Putin death explosion limousine")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Newsweek reports that a limousine from Vladimir Putin's motorcade caught fire near the FSB headquarters in Moscow (<image:9718>), with the cause of the fire unknown and no reported injuries. The article mentions Putin's reported paranoia about assassination plots. ([https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846](https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846))

The Economic Times reported that one of Putin's official limousines exploded in central Moscow, raising security concerns (<image:9727>, <image:9728>). The Sun reported that the explosion happened days after Zelensky's statement and amid rumors about Putin's health. ([https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms](https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms)) UAWire reports that one of Putin's luxury limousines exploded and caught fire near Moscow's FSB headquarters (<image:k>), with the fire starting in the engine of the "Aurus Senat" vehicle and no casualties recorded. ([https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow](https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow))


## Elaboration
The evidence suggests that one of Vladimir Putin's limousines was involved in an incident. Newsweek reports a fire, while The Economic Times and UAWire report an explosion. However, none of the reports confirm the death of Vladimir Putin. The reports mention security concerns and rumors about Putin's health, but they do not provide any information to support the claim that Putin died in an explosion.

The evidence indicates that an incident occurred involving one of Putin's limousines, but it does not confirm the claim that Putin died in an explosion.

To verify the claim, information is missing about Putin's presence in the vehicle during the incident and whether he was harmed.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results indicate that one of Putin's limousines was involved in an incident, with reports of a fire and an explosion. However, none of the reports confirm the death of Vladimir Putin.

The claim is not supported by the evidence. The reports do not confirm Putin's death. Therefore, the most appropriate decision option is `false`.

_________________________



SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Russian President Vladimir Putin has died in an explosion in one of his limousines."

## Actions
```
web_search("Vladimir Putin death explosion limousine")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
Newsweek reports that a limousine from Vladimir Putin's motorcade caught fire near the FSB headquarters in Moscow (<image:9718>), with the cause of the fire unknown and no reported injuries. The article mentions Putin's reported paranoia about assassination plots. ([https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846](https://www.newsweek.com/russia-putin-limousine-fire-video-2052846))

The Economic Times reported that one of Putin's official limousines exploded in central Moscow, raising security concerns (<image:9727>, <image:9728>). The Sun reported that the explosion happened days after Zelensky's statement and amid rumors about Putin's health. ([https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms](https://m.economictimes.com/news/international/world-news/blast-in-one-of-vladimir-putins-official-limousines-triggers-fresh-assassination-concerns/articleshow/119758547.cms)) UAWire reports that one of Putin's luxury limousines exploded and caught fire near Moscow's FSB headquarters (<image:k>), with the fire starting in the engine of the "Aurus Senat" vehicle and no casualties recorded. ([https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow](https://www.uawire.org/one-of-putin-s-luxury-limos-explodes-and-burns-in-moscow))


## Elaboration
The evidence suggests that one of Vladimir Putin's limousines was involved in an incident. Newsweek reports a fire, while The Economic Times and UAWire report an explosion. However, none of the reports confirm the death of Vladimir Putin. The reports mention security concerns and rumors about Putin's health, but they do not provide any information to support the claim that Putin died in an explosion.

The evidence indicates that an incident occurred involving one of Putin's limousines, but it does not confirm the claim that Putin died in an explosion.

To verify the claim, information is missing about Putin's presence in the vehicle during the incident and whether he was harmed.


## Final Judgement
The search results indicate that one of Putin's limousines was involved in an incident, with reports of a fire and an explosion. However, none of the reports confirm the death of Vladimir Putin.

The claim is not supported by the evidence. The reports do not confirm Putin's death. Therefore, the most appropriate decision option is `false`.


## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
Reports from various news sources, including Newsweek and The Economic Times, indicate that an incident occurred involving one of Vladimir Putin's limousines, with mentions of a fire and an explosion. However, none of the provided evidence confirms the death of Vladimir Putin, thus the claim is unsubstantiated.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
web_search("China Japan Russia invasion plan")
```

"Potsdam Declaration")<br>        <br>    *   [document](/wiki/Japanese_Instrument_of_Surrender "Japanese Instrument of Surrender")<br>        <br>    *   [End of World War II in Asia](/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Asia "End of World War II in Asia") |

Soviet invasion of Manchuria

[](#)

39 languages [Add topic](#) For the 1900 Russian invasion, see [Russian invasion of Manchuria](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Manchuria "Russian invasion of Manchuria")
.

Soviet invasion of ManchuriaPart of the [Soviet–Japanese War](/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_War "Soviet–Japanese War")
 of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Manchuria_Operation_map-en.svg/330px-Manchuria_Operation_map-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Manchuria_Operation_map-en.svg)
  
Soviet gains in North East Asia, August 1945

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| Date | 9–20 August 1945 |
| Location | [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria")<br>, [Inner Mongolia](/wiki/Inner_Mongolia "Inner Mongolia")<br>, and northern [Korea](/wiki/Korea "Korea") |
| Result | Soviet victory |
| Territorial  <br>changes | Collapse of Japanese puppet states<br><br>*   Partition of the Korean Peninsula at the [38th parallel](/wiki/Division_of_Korea "Division of Korea")<br>    .<br>*   Most of Manchuria and Inner Mongolia are returned to [the Nationalist government of China](/wiki/Nationalist_government "Nationalist government")<br>     by a 1945 [bilateral agreement](/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship_and_Alliance "Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance")<br>    <br>*   Parts of [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria")<br>     and [Inner Mongolia](/wiki/Inner_Mongolia "Inner Mongolia")<br>     are secretly handed over to the [Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party")<br>     [guerrillas](/wiki/Guerrilla "Guerrilla")<br>     after the Soviet withdrawal in 1946 |

Belligerents**[Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II")
**:  
 ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg.png)[Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")

Strength

[![Soviet Union](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 **Soviet Union:**

*   1,577,725 troops[\[3\]](#cite_note-glantz378-3)
    
*   27,086 artillery pieces
*   1,152 rocket launchers
*   5,556 tanks and self-propelled guns
*   3,721 aircraft
*   [![Mongolian People's Republic](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Flag_of_the_Mongolian_People%27s_Republic_%281945%E2%80%931992%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Mongolian_People%27s_Republic_%281945%E2%80%931992%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Republic "Mongolian People's Republic")
     **Mongolia:**
*   16,000 troops

* * *

*   **Total:**
*   1,593,725 troops
*   27,086 artillery pieces
*   1,152 rocket launchers
*   5,556 tanks and self-propelled guns
*   3,721 aircraft

[![Empire of Japan](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")
 **Japan:**

*   _Manchuria:_
*   665,500 soldiers and sailors[\[4\]](#cite_note-:1-4)
    [\[a\]](#cite_note-6)
    
*   290 tanks[\[6\]](#cite_note-7)
    
*   1,042 aircraft (232 combat)[\[7\]](#cite_note-:2-8)
    [\[b\]](#cite_note-9)
    
*   _Korea:_
*   335,900 soldiers and sailors[\[4\]](#cite_note-:1-4)
      
    ~80 tanks[\[c\]](#cite_note-10)
    
*   962 aircraft (395 combat)[\[7\]](#cite_note-:2-8)
    
*   [![Manchukuo](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Flag_of_Manchukuo.svg/40px-Flag_of_Manchukuo.svg.png)](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo")
     **Manchukuo:**
*   170,000[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
    –200,000 troops[\[8\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJowett53-11)
    
*   [![Mengjiang](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Flag_of_the_Mengjiang.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Mengjiang.svg.png)](/wiki/Mengjiang "Mengjiang")
     **Mengjiang:**
*   44,000 troops

* * *

*   **Total:**
*   1,215,400–1,245,400 troops and sailor
*   370 tanks
*   2,004 aircraft (627 combat)

Casualties and losses

[![Soviet Union](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union_%281936_%E2%80%93_1955%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 **Soviet Union:**

*   9,780–12,031 killed
*   24,425 wounded[\[9\]](#cite_note-12)
    [\[10\]](#cite_note-Coox,_Alvin_D._1939-13)
    
*   300+ tanks destroyed[\[11\]](#cite_note-14)
    
*   [![Mongolian People's Republic](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Flag_of_the_Mongolian_People%27s_Republic_%281945%E2%80%931992%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Mongolian_People%27s_Republic_%281945%E2%80%931992%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Republic "Mongolian People's Republic")
     **Mongolia:**
*   72 killed
*   125 wounded[\[12\]](#cite_note-15)
    

* * *

*   **Total:**
*   9,852–12,103 killed
*   24,550 wounded
*   78 Soviet tanks and SPGs
*   62 Soviet combat aircraft[\[13\]](#cite_note-16)
    

[![Empire of Japan](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_Japan_%281870%E2%80%931999%29.svg.png)](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")
 **Japanese medical records:**

*   21,389 killed[\[14\]](#cite_note-17)
    [\[d\]](#cite_note-claim-18)
    
*   Unknown captured in combat
*   Large amounts of equipment captured[\[e\]](#cite_note-19)
    
*   [![Manchukuo](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Flag_of_Manchukuo.svg/40px-Flag_of_Manchukuo.svg.png)](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo")
     **Manchukuo:**
*   Most troops deserted beforehand[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
    
*   [![Mengjiang](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Flag_of_the_Mengjiang.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_Mengjiang.svg.png)](/wiki/Mengjiang "Mengjiang")
     **Mengjiang:**
*   Most troops deserted beforehand[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
    

* * *

*   **Soviet claim:**
*   83,737 killed
*   20,000 wounded[\[d\]](#cite_note-claim-18)
    
*   594,000–609,000 [POWs](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war")
    
*   861–925 aircraft
*   369–600 tanks
*   2,576–3,704 guns and mortars captured
*   2,129–2,300 other vehicles captured[\[f\]](#cite_note-20)
    [\[g\]](#cite_note-21)

| --- |
| Manchuria<br><br>*   [Khingan–Mukden](/wiki/Khingan%E2%80%93Mukden_Operation "Khingan–Mukden Operation")<br>    *   [Gegenmiao](/wiki/Gegenmiao_massacre "Gegenmiao massacre")<br>        <br>*   [Harbin–Kirin](/wiki/Harbin%E2%80%93Kirin_Operation "Harbin–Kirin Operation")<br>    *   [Mutanchiang](/wiki/Battle_of_Mutanchiang "Battle of Mutanchiang")<br>        <br>    *   [Hutou [Unggi](/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Unggi&action=edit&redlink=1 "Battle of Unggi (page does not exist)")<br>    <br>*   [Rason](/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Rason&action=edit&redlink=1 "Battle of Rason (page does not exist)")<br>    <br>*   [Chongjin](/wiki/Seishin_Operation "Seishin Operation")<br>    <br>*   [Kimchaek](/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Kimchaek&action=edit&redlink=1 "Battle of Kimchaek (page does not exist)")<br>    <br>*   [Wonsan](/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Wonsan&action=edit&redlink=1 "Battle of Wonsan (page does not exist)")<br>    <br><br>[Japan](/wiki/Japan_campaign "Japan campaign")<br><br>*   [South Sakhalin](/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_South_Sakhalin "Soviet invasion of South Sakhalin")<br>    *   [Maoka](/wiki/Soviet_assault_on_Maoka "Soviet assault on Maoka")<br>        <br>    *   [Toro](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_assault_on_Toro&action=edit&redlink=1 "Soviet assault on Toro (page does not exist)")<br>         \[[ru](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%94%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82_%D0%B2_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82_%D0%A2%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE "ru:Десант в порт Торо")<br>        \]<br>    *   [Otomari](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_assault_on_Otomari&action=edit&redlink=1 "Soviet assault on Otomari (page does not exist)")<br>        <br>*   [Kuril Islands](/wiki/Invasion_of_the_Kuril_Islands "Invasion of the Kuril Islands")<br>    *   [Shumshu](/wiki/Battle_of_Shumshu "Battle of Shumshu")<br>        <br>*   [Hokkaido (cancelled)](/wiki/Proposed_Soviet_invasion_of_Hokkaido "Proposed Soviet invasion of Hokkaido") |     |

The **Soviet invasion of Manchuria**, formally known as the **Manchurian Strategic Offensive Operation**[\[15\]](#cite_note-22)
 or simply the **Manchurian Operation** (Маньчжурская операция) and sometimes **Operation August Storm**,[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 began on 9 August 1945 with the [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 invasion of the [Empire of Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")
's [puppet state](/wiki/Puppet_state "Puppet state")
 of [Manchukuo](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo")
, which was situated in Japanese-occupied [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria")
. The Japanese did not have any concrete evidence as to when or where any invasion would occur.[\[17\]](#cite_note-Drea-24)
 They had estimated that an attack was not likely before the spring of 1946, but the _[Stavka](/wiki/Stavka "Stavka")
_ had in fact been planning for a mid-August offensive, successfully [concealing the buildup](/wiki/Russian_military_deception "Russian military deception")
 of a force of 90 divisions. The Kwantung Army commanders were engaged in a planning exercise at the time of the invasion, and were away from their forces for the first eighteen hours of conflict.

The Russians treated the Japanese with the utmost cruelty after their deadly attack on Japan's Kwantung Army in Manchuria just days before Japan's surrender.[\[38\]](#cite_note-46)
 Japanese forces were overwhelmed by Soviet attacks. Another group of Japanese women that were with Ikeda Hiroko that on 15 August tried to flee to Harbin but returned to their settlements were raped by Soviet soldiers.[\[79\]](#cite_note-87)

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: See also")\

Explanatory notes
-----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Explanatory notes")\
\]

1. The Soviets continued to occupy northern Korea until 1948 and the [Port Arthur](/wiki/Port_Arthur,_China "Port Arthur, China")
 naval base until 1955.

Soviet forces also captured scientists of the Kwantung Army's [Unit 731](/wiki/Unit_731 "Unit 731")
 biological and chemical warfare division, sentencing them in the 1949 [Khabarovsk war crimes trials](/wiki/Khabarovsk_war_crimes_trials "Khabarovsk war crimes trials")
 while allegedly using their information and experience in the [Soviet biological weapons program](/wiki/Soviet_biological_weapons_program "Soviet biological weapons program")
.

Summary
-------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Summary")\
\]

Main article: [Soviet–Japanese War § Summary](/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_War#Summary "Soviet–Japanese War")

As agreed with the United Kingdom and the United States (Western Allies) at the [Tehran Conference](/wiki/Tehran_Conference "Tehran Conference")
 in November 1943 and the [Yalta Conference](/wiki/Yalta_Conference "Yalta Conference")
 in February 1945, the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
 entered World War II's [Pacific Theatre](/wiki/Pacific_War "Pacific War")
 within three months of the [end of the war in Europe](/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day "Victory in Europe Day")
. Many Soviet units had crossed Siberia in their vehicles to avoid straining the rail link.[\[33\]](#cite_note-40)

The Japanese were caught completely by surprise upon receiving the Soviet declaration of war an hour before midnight on 8 August, now facing a simultaneous invasion on three fronts that began just after midnight on 9 August.

Combatants
----------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Combatants")\
\]

### Soviets

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Soviets")\
\]

The Far East Command,[\[2\]](#cite_note-Battlefield_Series-2)
 under [Marshal of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Marshal_of_the_Soviet_Union "Marshal of the Soviet Union")
 Aleksandr Vasilevsky, had a plan to conquer Manchuria that was simple but huge in scale,[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 calling for a massive [pincer movement](/wiki/Pincer_movement "Pincer movement")
 over all of Manchuria. This secondary objective was to be carried out by the [25th Army](/wiki/25th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "25th Army (Soviet Union)")
.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 Meanwhile, the [35th Army](/wiki/35th_Army_(Russia) "35th Army (Russia)")
 was tasked with capturing the cities of [Boli](/wiki/Boli_County "Boli County")
 (or Poli), [Linkou](/w/index.php?title=Linkou,_Heilongjiang&action=edit&redlink=1 "Linkou, Heilongjiang (page does not exist)")
 and [Mishan](/wiki/Mishan "Mishan")
.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)

#### 2nd Far Eastern Front

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: 2nd Far Eastern Front")\
\]

The 2nd Far Eastern Front, under General [Maksim Purkayev](/wiki/Maksim_Purkayev "Maksim Purkayev")
, included:[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)

*   [2nd Red Banner Army](/wiki/Soviet_Second_Army "Soviet Second Army")
    
*   [15th Army](/wiki/15th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "15th Army (Soviet Union)")
    
*   [16th Army](/wiki/16th_Army_(Soviet_Union) "16th Army (Soviet Union)")
     (whose 56th Rifle Corps was its only formation to see combat, on [South Sakhalin](/wiki/South_Sakhalin "South Sakhalin")
    )
*   [5th Separate Rifle Corps](/wiki/5th_Separate_Rifle_Corps "5th Separate Rifle Corps")
    
*   [Chuguevsk Operational Group](/w/index.php?title=Chuguevsk_Operational_Group&action=edit&redlink=1 "Chuguevsk Operational Group (page does not exist)")
    
*   [Amur Military Flotilla](/wiki/Amur_Military_Flotilla "Amur Military Flotilla")
    
*   [10th Air Army](/wiki/10th_Air_Army "10th Air Army")
    

The 2nd Far Eastern Front was deployed in a supporting attack role.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 Its objectives were the cities of Harbin and Qiqihar,[\[2\]](#cite_note-Battlefield_Series-2)
 and to prevent an orderly withdrawal to the south by the Japanese forces.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 The front also included the [88th Separate Rifle Brigade](/wiki/88th_Separate_Rifle_Brigade "88th Separate Rifle Brigade")
, composed of Chinese and Korean guerrillas of the [Northeast Anti-Japanese United Army](/wiki/Northeast_Anti-Japanese_United_Army "Northeast Anti-Japanese United Army")
 who had retreated into the USSR in the beginning of the 1940s. Approximately one-third of its strength was in combat support and services.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)
 The Soviet plan incorporated all of the experience in maneuver warfare that they had acquired in fighting the Germans.[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)

### Japanese

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Japanese")\
\]

The [Kwantung Army](/wiki/Kwantung_Army "Kwantung Army")
 of the [Imperial Japanese Army](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army "Imperial Japanese Army")
, under General [Otozo Yamada](/wiki/Otozo_Yamada "Otozo Yamada")
, was the major part of the Japanese occupation forces in Manchuria and Korea, and consisted of two Area Armies and three independent armies:[\[1\]](#cite_note-Glantz-1)

*   [First Area Army](/wiki/Japanese_First_Area_Army "Japanese First Area Army")
     (northeastern Manchukuo), including:
    *   [3rd Army](/wiki/Japanese_Third_Army "Japanese Third Army")
        
    *   [5th Army](/wiki/Japanese_Fifth_Army "Japanese Fifth Army")
        
*   [Third Area Army](/wiki/Japanese_Third_Area_Army "Japanese Third Area Army")
     (southwestern Manchukuo), including:
    *   [30th Army](/wiki/Japanese_Thirtieth_Army "Japanese Thirtieth Army")
        
    *   [44th Army](/wiki/Japanese_Forty-Fourth_Army "Japanese Forty-Fourth Army")
        
*   Independent units:
    *   [4th Army](/wiki/Japanese_Fourth_Army "Japanese Fourth Army")
         (an independent field army responsible for northern Manchuria)
    *   [34th Army](/wiki/Japanese_Thirty-Fourth_Army "Japanese Thirty-Fourth Army")
         (an independent field army responsible for the areas between the Third and Seventeenth Area Armies in northern Korea)
    *   [Seventeenth Area Army](/wiki/Japanese_Seventeenth_Area_Army "Japanese Seventeenth Area Army")
         (responsible for Korea; assigned to the Kwantung Army at the eleventh hour, to no avail)

Each _Area Army_ (_Homen Gun_, the equivalent of a [Western](/wiki/Western_world "Western world")
 "army") had headquarters units and units attached directly to the Area Army, in addition to the field armies (the equivalent of a Western corps). Soviet paratroopers destroyed the Kwantung Army from behind its own lines, while Japanese anti-tank shells bounced off the sides of Soviet tanks.[\[39\]](#cite_note-47)
 The Japanese forces in Manchuria retreated in fear.[\[40\]](#cite_note-48)

Japanese troops and able-bodied Japanese men in Manchuria were taken prisoner by the Russians and transported to labor camps in Siberia, where many Japanese men would die.[\[41\]](#cite_note-49)
 From the Russians' perspective, this was seen as revenge for Russia's defeat in the [Russo-Japanese War](/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War "Russo-Japanese War")
 of 1905.[\[42\]](#cite_note-50)
 The stories of how poorly the Soviets treated the Japanese were brought to [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing")
 by Japanese evacuees of Manchuria, creating panic among the Japanese population; however, the Russians honored their agreement with Chiang Kai-shek by not entering China proper.[\[43\]](#cite_note-51)

Japanese communication infrastructure was poor, and the Japanese lost communication with forward units very early on."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Soviet Union invaded the Empire of Japan's puppet state of Manchukuo on August 9, 1945, as part of World War II. The invasion, known as the Manchurian Strategic Offensive Operation, caught the Japanese by surprise. The Kwantung Army, the main Japanese force in the area, was unprepared. The Soviets employed a large-scale pincer movement, with the 2nd Far Eastern Front playing a supporting role. The Japanese forces, including the Kwantung Army, were overwhelmed. The Soviets captured Japanese soldiers and civilians, with many being sent to labor camps in Siberia. The invasion resulted in significant casualties and the collapse of Japanese control in the region.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea): 
Content: "Advertisement

[Japan](/topics/japan?module=breadcrumb&pgtype=article)

[This Week in Asia](/week-asia?module=breadcrumb&pgtype=article)
[Politics](/week-asia/politics?module=breadcrumb&pgtype=article)

Russia’s uncovered secret war plans target 160 sites in Japan and South Korea
=============================================================================

### 

Leaked Russian military documents reveal plans to target civilian infrastructure like nuclear power plants and tunnels, raising concerns about potential war crimes

Reading Time:**4 minutes**

[Why you can trust SCMP](/policies-and-standards#participation)

17

!A view of the Kanmon Straits from Mount. Photo: Shutterstock <image:3874>

[Julian Ryall](/author/julian-ryall)

Published: 4:19pm, 1 Jan 2025Updated: 2:05pm, 2 Jan 2025

The Russian military has identified 160 priority targets in [Japan](https://www.scmp.com/topics/japan?module=inline&pgtype=article)
 and [South Korea](https://www.scmp.com/topics/south-korea?module=inline&pgtype=article)
 in the event of a conflict with [Nato](https://www.scmp.com/topics/nato?module=inline&pgtype=article)
 expanding into East Asia, according to secret documents obtained by the Financial Times.

Advertisement

While many targets include legitimate military sites like airfields, radar installations and naval installations, the list also features civilian infrastructure such as nuclear power plants, factories, and transport tunnels.

Deliberately attacking such civilian sites, in the same way Russian forces have done in [Ukraine](https://www.scmp.com/topics/ukraine?module=inline&pgtype=article)
, would constitute a war crime, one analyst said.

In a story published on Tuesday, the British paper reported on 29 leaked Russian military documents used for training officers for potential conflicts in northeastern Asia, shared by “Western sources.”

Although the documents are dated from 2008 to 2014, James Brown, an international relations professor at Temple University in Tokyo, who specialises in Russian affairs, told This Week in Asia that the core elements of Russian strategy and targeting data are likely to remain relevant, albeit updated and enhanced with more recent information.

> It’s obvious why radar facilities and airbases would be targets, but nuclear power plants? Road and rail tunnels?

James Brown, analyst

“Of course, the Russians will have plans for targets in the event of a war breaking out because they need to know what they have to hit,” Brown said.

Advertisement

Get through articles 2x faster

1.25x

250 WPM

Slow

Average

Fast

00:0000:00

1.25x"

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The South China Morning Post published an article on January 1, 2025, discussing leaked Russian military documents. The documents reveal plans to target 160 sites in Japan and South Korea, including civilian infrastructure. <image:3874>

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1

Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/6/russia-china-naval-forces-to-carry-out-joint-asia-pacific-patrol-report): 
Content: "MANDATORY CREDIT.](/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/2025-07-31T162939Z_2038806586_RC2IXFAQM5ID_RTRMADP_3_RUSSIA-CHINA-NAVY-DRILLS-1754455741.jpg?resize=770%2C513&quality=80)

People take part in a ceremony marking the start of the upcoming Russian-Chinese joint naval drills in the Sea of Japan, in Vladivostok, Russia, on July 31, 2025 \[Handout/Russian Defence Ministry/Russia's Pacific Fleet via Reuters\]

Published On 6 Aug 20256 Aug 2025

Russian and Chinese naval vessels plan to conduct a joint patrol in the Asia Pacific region, following recent [exercises in the Sea of Japan](/news/2025/8/3/china-and-russia-begin-joint-military-drills-in-sea-of-japan)
, Russia’s official Interfax has reported.

Citing a statement on Wednesday from the Russian Pacific Fleet’s press service, Interfax said that ships from the Russian Navy and China’s People’s Liberation Army (PLA) Navy “will form a new task group to carry out joint patrol missions in the Asia-Pacific region”.

Recommended Stories
-------------------

list of 3 items

list 1 of 3

### [China and Russia begin joint military drills in Sea of Japan](/news/2025/8/3/china-and-russia-begin-joint-military-drills-in-sea-of-japan)

list 2 of 3

### [Philippines, India hold first joint naval drill in disputed South China Sea](/news/2025/8/4/philippines-india-hold-first-joint-naval-drill-in-disputed-south-china-sea)

list 3 of 3

### [Australia, Japan strike largest defence deal for advanced warships](/news/2025/8/5/australia-japan-strike-largest-defence-deal-for-advanced-warships)

end of list

“After replenishing supplies from logistics vessels, the crews of the Russian Navy and the PLA Navy will form a new detachment to carry out joint patrol tasks in the Asia-Pacific region,” the news agency said.

Russia is conducting a series of military exercises with China in response to the build-up of US military potential in the Asia Pacific region, Interfax said, citing Russia’s chief of staff, Valery Gerasimov, in 2022.

Moscow and Beijing have already conducted joint air patrols in the Asia Pacific region since 2019, it added.

The joint patrol announcement comes as the two countries conclude five days of joint naval drills in the Sea of Japan that focused on anti-submarine and air defence missions.

During the final phase of the exercises, Russia’s large anti-submarine ship Admiral Tributs and the corvette Gromky, together with the Chinese destroyers Shaoxing and Urumqi, carried out live-fire drills while crews practised searching for and neutralising a mock enemy submarine, Interfax reported.

Russia’s Pacific Fleet earlier said that the drills were defensive in nature and not directed against any other countries.

The reported formation of the Asia Pacific joint patrol comes as China modernises and upgrades its naval fleet to become a “blue water” force, capable of carrying out long-range operations in the world’s oceans, similar to the United States and other Western forces.

[Russia and China](/news/2024/9/10/china-russia-to-conduct-joint-naval-and-air-drills-this-month)
, which signed a “no-limits” strategic partnership shortly before Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, conduct regular exercises to rehearse coordination between their armed forces and send a deterrent signal to adversaries.

Source: Al Jazeera

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```

```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria): 
Content: The Soviet Union invaded the Empire of Japan's puppet state of Manchukuo on August 9, 1945, as part of World War II. The invasion, known as the Manchurian Strategic Offensive Operation, caught the Japanese by surprise. The Kwantung Army, the main Japanese force in the area, was unprepared. The Soviets employed a large-scale pincer movement, with the 2nd Far Eastern Front playing a supporting role. The Japanese forces, including the Kwantung Army, were overwhelmed. The Soviets captured Japanese soldiers and civilians, with many being sent to labor camps in Siberia. The invasion resulted in significant casualties and the collapse of Japanese control in the region.


From [Source](https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea): 
Content: The South China Morning Post published an article on January 1, 2025, discussing leaked Russian military documents. The documents reveal plans to target 160 sites in Japan and South Korea, including civilian infrastructure. <image:3874>


From [Source](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/6/russia-china-naval-forces-to-carry-out-joint-asia-pacific-patrol-report): 
Content: Al Jazeera reports that Russian and Chinese naval vessels plan to conduct a joint patrol in the Asia Pacific region. The announcement follows joint naval drills in the Sea of Japan. <image:k> The article was published on August 6, 2025.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Soviet Union invaded Manchukuo in 1945, overwhelming Japanese forces and leading to significant casualties ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)). Leaked Russian military documents reveal plans to target 160 sites in Japan and South Korea ([https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea](https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea)).

Russian and Chinese naval vessels plan to conduct a joint patrol in the Asia Pacific region ([https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/6/russia-china-naval-forces-to-carry-out-joint-asia-pacific-patrol-report](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/6/russia-china-naval-forces-to-carry-out-joint-asia-pacific-patrol-report)). <image:3874> <image:k>

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.

* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan Russia invasion plan")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Soviet Union invaded Manchukuo in 1945, overwhelming Japanese forces and leading to significant casualties ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)). Leaked Russian military documents reveal plans to target 160 sites in Japan and South Korea ([https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea](https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea)).

# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence does not support the claim that China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation. The provided sources mention a Soviet invasion of Manchuria, leaked Russian plans to target sites in Japan and South Korea, and joint naval patrols between Russia and China in the Asia Pacific region. None of these sources mention any invasion plans by China or Japan against Russia.

The evidence suggests that Russia and China are cooperating militarily, but this does not imply an invasion plan. The image shows a ship in Japan.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```

The Soviet Union invaded Manchukuo in 1945, overwhelming Japanese forces and leading to significant casualties ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)). Leaked Russian military documents reveal plans to target 160 sites in Japan and South Korea ([https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea](https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea)).

## Elaboration

The provided sources mention a Soviet invasion of Manchuria, leaked Russian plans to target sites in Japan and South Korea, and joint naval patrols between Russia and China in the Asia Pacific region. None of these sources mention any invasion plans by China or Japan against Russia.

The evidence suggests that Russia and China are cooperating militarily, but this does not imply an invasion plan. The image shows a ship in Japan.

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation."

## Actions
```
web_search("China Japan Russia invasion plan")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Soviet Union invaded Manchukuo in 1945, overwhelming Japanese forces and leading to significant casualties ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)). Leaked Russian military documents reveal plans to target 160 sites in Japan and South Korea ([https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea](https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3293037/russias-uncovered-secret-war-plans-target-160-sites-japan-and-south-korea)).

Russian and Chinese naval vessels plan to conduct a joint patrol in the Asia Pacific region ([https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/6/russia-china-naval-forces-to-carry-out-joint-asia-pacific-patrol-report](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/6/russia-china-naval-forces-to-carry-out-joint-asia-pacific-patrol-report)). <image:3874> <image:k>


## Elaboration
The evidence does not support the claim that China and Japan plan to invade the Russian Federation. The provided sources mention a Soviet invasion of Manchuria, leaked Russian plans to target sites in Japan and South Korea, and joint naval patrols between Russia and China in the Asia Pacific region. None of these sources mention any invasion plans by China or Japan against Russia.

The evidence suggests that Russia and China are cooperating militarily, but this does not imply an invasion plan. The image shows a ship in Japan.


## Final Judgement
The evidence does not support the claim. The search results show historical events and current military activities, but no evidence of a planned invasion of Russia by China or Japan.

`false`


## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is unsupported by the evidence. While there is evidence of historical conflicts, such as the Soviet invasion of Manchuria ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria)), and current military cooperation between Russia and China, there is no evidence to suggest that China and Japan are planning to invade Russia.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

```

* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)

* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

# Search Result
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Slavic_name): Found exact image on website with title: East Slavic name - Wikipedia
Content: "[Jump to content](#bodyContent)

[![Page semi-protected](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1b/Semi-protection-shackle.svg/20px-Semi-protection-shackle.svg.png)](/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#semi "This article is semi-protected until September 3, 2025 at 07:44 UTC.")

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png)

**This article has multiple issues.** Please help **[improve it](/wiki/Special:EditPage/East_Slavic_name "Special:EditPage/East Slavic name")
** or discuss these issues on the **[talk page](/wiki/Talk:East_Slavic_name "Talk:East Slavic name")

| ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg/40px-Text_document_with_red_question_mark.svg.png) | This article includes a list of [general references](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#General_references "Wikipedia:Citing sources")<br>, but **it lacks sufficient corresponding [inline citations](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Inline_citations "Wikipedia:Citing sources")<br>**. )_

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Pasport_RF.jpg/250px-Pasport_RF.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pasport_RF.jpg)

A Russian citizen's _(Yevgeniy Aleksandrovich Imyarek)_ [internal passport](/wiki/Internal_passport_of_Russia "Internal passport of Russia")
. The lower page includes the lines: Фамилия ("Family name"), Имя ("Name") and Отчество ("Patronymic").

**East Slavic naming customs** are the traditional way of identifying a person's [given name](/wiki/Given_name "Given name")
, [patronymic](/wiki/Patronymic "Patronymic")
 name, and [family name](/wiki/Family_name "Family name")
 in [East Slavic cultures](/wiki/East_Slavic_languages "East Slavic languages")
 in Russia and some countries formerly part of the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire")
 and the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
.

They are used commonly in [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia")
, [Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine")
, [Belarus](/wiki/Belarus "Belarus")
, [Moldova](/wiki/Moldova "Moldova")
, [Kazakhstan](/wiki/Kazakhstan "Kazakhstan")
, [Turkmenistan](/wiki/Turkmenistan "Turkmenistan")
, [Uzbekistan](/wiki/Uzbekistan "Uzbekistan")
, and to a lesser extent in [Kyrgyzstan](/wiki/Kyrgyzstan "Kyrgyzstan")
, [Tajikistan](/wiki/Tajikistan "Tajikistan")
, [Azerbaijan](/wiki/Azerbaijan "Azerbaijan")
, [Armenia](/wiki/Armenia "Armenia")
 and [Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_(country) "Georgia (country)")
.

| Name | Belarusian example | Russian example | Ukrainian example |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| First name ([given name](/wiki/Given_name "Given name")<br>) | [Belarusian](/wiki/Belarusian_language "Belarusian language")<br>: Уладзімір, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Belarusian "Romanization of Belarusian")<br>: _Uladzimir_ | [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language")<br>: Владимир, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian "Romanization of Russian")<br>: _Vladimir_ | [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainian_language "Ukrainian language")<br>: Володимир, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian "Romanization of Ukrainian")<br>: _Volodymyr_ |
| [Patronymic](/wiki/Patronymic "Patronymic") | [Belarusian](/wiki/Belarusian_language "Belarusian language")<br>: Антонавіч, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Belarusian "Romanization of Belarusian")<br>: _Antonavič_ | [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language")<br>: Антонович, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian "Romanization of Russian")<br>: _Antonovich_ | [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainian_language "Ukrainian language")<br>: Антонович, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian "Romanization of Ukrainian")<br>: _Antonovych_ |
| [Family name](/wiki/Family_name "Family name")<br> (surname) | [Belarusian](/wiki/Belarusian_language "Belarusian language")<br>: Іваноў, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Belarusian "Romanization of Belarusian")<br>: _Ivanoŭ_ | [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language")<br>: Иванов, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian "Romanization of Russian")<br>: _Ivanov_ | [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainian_language "Ukrainian language")<br>: Іванів, [romanized](/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian "Romanization of Ukrainian")<br>: _Ivaniv_ |

Given names
-----------

East Slavic parents select a [given name](/wiki/Russian_personal_name "Russian personal name")
 for a newborn child. Most first names in East Slavic languages originate from two sources:

*   [Eastern Orthodox Church](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church")
     tradition
*   [native pre-Christian Slavic lexicons](/wiki/Slavic_names "Slavic names")
    

Almost all first names are single. Doubled first names (as in, for example, [French](/wiki/French_name "French name")
, like _Jean-Luc_) are very rare and are from foreign influence. Most doubled first names are written with a hyphen: _Mariya-Tereza_.

### Males

| Belarusian variant | Russian variant | Ukrainian variant | Latin-alphabet transliteration[\[note 1\]](#cite_note-1)<br>  <br>(Belarusian / Russian / Ukrainian) | Origin | Comments |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Іван, Ян | Иван, Ян | Іван, Ян | Ivan, Jan / [Ivan](/wiki/Ivan_(name) "Ivan (name)")<br> / Ivan | [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language") | equivalent to _[John](/wiki/John_(given_name) "John (given name)")<br>_ |
| Якуб, Якаў | Иаков, Яков | Яків | Yakub, Yakau / Iakov, Yakov / Yakiv | Hebrew | equivalent to _[James](/wiki/James_(name) "James (name)")<br>_ or Jacob |
| Ілля | Илья | Ілля | Illa / [Ilia](/wiki/Ilya "Ilya")<br> / Illia | Hebrew | equivalent to _[Elijah](/wiki/Elijah "Elijah")<br>_ |
| Мікалай, Мікола | Николай | Микола | Mikałaj, Mikoła / Nikolai / Mykola, Mykolai | [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") | equivalent to _[Nicholas](/wiki/Nicholas "Nicholas")<br>_, meaning "Victory (of the) People" |
| Мiкiта | Никита | Микита | Mikita / [Nikita](/wiki/Nikita_(given_name) "Nikita (given name)")<br> / Mykyta | [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") | equivalent to "[Nicetas](/wiki/Nicetas "Nicetas")<br>", meaning "victorious one" (from Nike "victory") |
| Барыс | Борис | Борис | Barys / [Boris](/wiki/Boris_(given_name) "Boris (given name)")<br> / Borys | [Bulgar](/wiki/Bulgar_language "Bulgar language") | unclear, possibly "wolf", "short" or "snow leopard" |
| Уладзімір | Владимир | Володимир | Uładzimir / [Vladimir](/wiki/Vladimir_(name) "Vladimir (name)")<br> / Volodymyr | [Slavonic](/wiki/Slavonic_languages "Slavonic languages") | meaning "great/famous lord" (-мир comes from мѣръ and is not related to міръ or миръ, see also the name's [etymology](/wiki/Vladimir_(name)#Etymology "Vladimir (name)")<br>) Equivalent to Norse [Valdemar](/wiki/Waldemar "Waldemar") |
| Пётр, Пятро, Пятрусь | Пётр | Петро | Piotr, Piatro, Piatruś / Petr, Pyotr / Petro | Greek | equivalent to [Peter](/wiki/Peter_(given_name) "Peter (given name)") |
| Андрэй | Андрей | Андрій | Andrej / Andrei / Andrii | Greek | equivalent to [Andrew](/wiki/Andrew "Andrew") |
| Аляксандр | Александр | Олександр, Олекса | Alaksandr / Aleksandr / Oleksandr, Oleksa | Greek | equivalent to [Alexander](/wiki/Alexander "Alexander") |
| Піліп | Филипп | Пилип | Pilip / Filipp / Pylyp | Greek | from Greek Φίλιππος (Phílippos), meaning "fond of horses". Equivalent to [Philip](/wiki/Philip "Philip")<br>. |
| Дзмітры, Зміцер | Дмитрий | Дмитро | Dzmitry, Zmicier / [Dmitrii](/wiki/Dmitry "Dmitry")<br> / Dmytro | Greek | from Greek Δημήτριος ([Demétrios](/wiki/Demetrius "Demetrius")<br>), meaning "of [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter")<br>" |
| Сяргей | Сергей | Сергій | Siarhiej / [Sergei](/wiki/Sergius_(name) "Sergius (name)")<br> / Serhii | Latin | from the [Roman](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome")<br> _nomen_ (patrician family name) _**Sergius**_, itself from a more ancient [Etruscan](/wiki/Etruscan_civilization "Etruscan civilization")<br> name |
| Леанід, Лявон | Леонид | Леонід | Leanid, Lavon / [Leonid](/wiki/Leonid "Leonid")<br> / Leonid | Greek | from Greek _[Leonidas](/wiki/Leonidas "Leonidas")<br>_, meaning "Son of the Lion" |
| Віктар | Виктор | Віктор | Viktar / Viktor / Viktor | Latin | meaning "Conqueror" |

| Павел, Павал, Паўло | Павел | Павло | Pavał, Paŭło / Pavel / Pavlo | Latin | equivalent to [Paul](/wiki/Paul_(name) "Paul (name)") |

1.  **[^](#cite_ref-1)
    ** The same [romanization](/wiki/Romanization "Romanization")
     system is used for all three languages for comparative purposes. For the official romanization systems of Russian, Ukrainian, and Belarusian, which will be used throughout the rest of the article, see [romanization of Russian](/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian "Romanization of Russian")
    , [romanization of Ukrainian](/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian "Romanization of Ukrainian")
    , and [romanization of Belarusian](/wiki/Romanization_of_Belarusian "Romanization of Belarusian")
    , respectively.

### Females

| Belarusian variant | Russian variant | Ukrainian variant | Latin-alphabet transliteration  <br>(Belarusian / Russian / Ukrainian) | Origin | Comments |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Настасся, Наста | Анастасия | Анастасія | Nastassia, Nasta / Anastasiya / Anastasiia | Greek | from Greek Ἀναστασία ([Anastasia](/wiki/Anastasia "Anastasia")<br>) meaning "she of the Resurrection" |

| Марыя | Мария | Марія | Maryja / Mariya / Mariia | Hebrew | equivalent to [Mary](/wiki/Mary_(given_name) "Mary (given name)") |

| Любоў | Любовь | Любов | Luboŭ / Lyubov / Liubоv | Slavonic | meaning "Love"; a [calque](/wiki/Calque "Calque")<br> of the Greek Ἀγάπη |
| Соф'я | София, Софья | Софія | Sofja / Sofiya, Sofya / Sofiia | Greek | equivalent to Sophia, meaning "Wisdom" |

### Forms

Being highly [synthetic languages](/wiki/Synthetic_languages "Synthetic languages")
, the East Slavic ones treat personal names as [grammatical](/wiki/Grammatical "Grammatical")
 nouns and apply the same rules of [inflection](/wiki/Inflection "Inflection")
 and [derivation](/wiki/Derivation_(linguistics) "Derivation (linguistics)")
 to them as for other nouns. So one can create many forms with different degrees of affection and familiarity by adding the corresponding suffixes to the auxiliary stem derived from the original name. The auxiliary stem may be identical to the word stem of the full name (the full name Жанна _Zhanna_ can have the suffixes added directly to the stem Жанн- _Zhann-_ like Жанн**очка** _Zhann**ochka**_), and most names have the auxiliary stem derived unproductively (the Russian name Михаил _Mikhail_ has the auxiliary stem Миш- _Mish-_, which produces such name-forms as Миш**а** _Mish**a**_, Миш**енька** _Mish**enka**_, Миш**уня** _Mish**unya**_ etc., not \***Михаил**ушка _**Mikhail**ushka_).

Unlike English, in which the use of diminutive forms is optional even between close friends, in East Slavonic languages, such forms are obligatory in certain contexts because of the strong [T–V distinction](/wiki/T%E2%80%93V_distinction "T–V distinction")
: the T-form of address usually requires the short form of the counterpart's name. Also, unlike other languages with prominent use of name suffixes, such as Japanese, the use of derived name forms is mostly limited to the T-addressing: there is no way to make the name more formal than the plain unsuffixed full form, and usually no suffixes can be added to the family name.

Most commonly, Russian philologists distinguish the following forms of given names:

| Name form | Example | Formation | Comments |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Full | _Анна_ (Anna) | full name stem + case ending | \-  |
| Short | _Ан**я**_ (An**ya**) | short name stem + II declension ending | most common for informal communication, comparable to Western name-only form of address _(Ann, John)_, or Japanese surname-only, or _surname/name -kun_ |
| Diminutive | _Ань**к**а_ (An**k**a) | short name stem + -к- _\-k-_ + II declension ending | expresses familiarity, may be considered rude when used between people who are not close friends. Comparable to English diminutives _(Annie, Willy)_ or Japanese unsuffixed names |
| Affective diminutive | _Ан**ечк**а_ (An**yechk**a) | short name stem + -ечк/очк/оньк/усь/юсь/уль/юль- _\-echk/ochk/on'k/us/yus/ul/yul-_ + II declension ending | most intimate and affectionate form, comparable to German diminutives _(Ännchen)_ or Japanese _\-chan_ suffixes |

#### Short forms

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Tsvetaeva.jpg/250px-Tsvetaeva.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tsvetaeva.jpg)

[Marina Tsvetaeva](/wiki/Marina_Tsvetaeva "Marina Tsvetaeva")
, a Russian poet. The name "Marina" traditionally has no short form.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Nikolay_Ge_040.jpg/250px-Nikolay_Ge_040.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nikolay_Ge_040.jpg)

_Руслан_ (Ruslan), a character in [Alexander Pushkin](/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin "Alexander Pushkin")
's poem _[Ruslan and Ludmila](/wiki/Ruslan_and_Ludmila "Ruslan and Ludmila")
_. The short form for _Руслан_ (Ruslan) is _Руся_ (Rusya).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Mikola_II.jpg/250px-Mikola_II.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mikola_II.jpg)

Николай II ([Nicholas II](/wiki/Nicholas_II "Nicholas II")
), the last Russian emperor. In private, [his wife](/wiki/Alexandra_Feodorovna_(Alix_of_Hesse) "Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)")
 addressed him as Nicki, in the German manner, rather than _Коля_ (Kolya), which is the East Slavic short form of his name.

The "short name" (Russian: краткое имя _kratkoye imya_), historically also "half-name" (Russian: полуимя _poluimya_), is the simplest and most common name derivative. Bearing no suffix, it is produced [suppletively](/wiki/Suppletion "Suppletion")
 and always has the declension noun ending for both males and females, thus making short forms of certain unisex names indistinguishable: for example, Sasha (Russian: Саша) is the short name for both the masculine name Aleksandr (Alexander) and the feminine form Aleksandra (Alexandra).

Some names, such as Zhanna (Jeana) and Mark, have no short forms; others may have two (or more) different forms. In the latter case, one form is usually more informal than the other.

| Full name (Cyrillic script) | Full name (Latin script) | Short forms (Cyrillic) | Short forms (Latin) |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Александр | Aleksandr (m) | Саша, Саня, Шура, ukr. Сашко, Лесь | Sasha, Sanya, Shura, ukr. Sashko, Les |
| Александра | Aleksandra (f) | Саша, Шура, ukr. Леся | Sasha, Shura, ukr. Lesia |
| Алексей | Aleksey (m) | Алёша, Лёша | Alyosha, Lyosha |
| Анастасия | Anastasia (f) | Настя, Стася | Nastya, Stasya (rare) |
| Анатолий | Anatoly (m) | Толя | Tolya |
